Devnagari script has  been used to write the   history of Rohida.
Rohida is  also  related to Lord Parshuram,  at the period of Mahabharata, Parshuram visited Rohida and established Lord Shiva temple and named it Jabeshwar  Mahadev Mandir which is  around 4  km from Rohida. References  
Rohida village
Rohida PIN
Rohida  in freedom  movement

Karl Wilhelm   (Vasily Georgievich) Brandt (Willi Brandt)  (18691923) was a German-Russian trumpeter, pedagogue, and composer. He was born and educated in Coburg, and after a period of  working alternatively in  the spa orchestra in Bad Oeynhausen and in Helsinki,  he moved to  Russia. He became principal trumpet of the Bolshoi Theater in  1890 and became first cornet in  1903. He succeeded Theodor   Richter  (18261901) as the trumpet professor of  the Moscow Conservatory in 1900, and also taught band orchestration there. He is considered the founder  of the Russian trumpet  school. His  34 Orchestral Etudes, is an important study material for modern  trumpet players. His two  Concert Pieces  for  trumpet and piano are   also  widely performed today. Brandt joined the  faculty of the  Saratov Conservatory in 1912. Among his students are Pyotr  Lyamin (18841968) who succeeded Brandt  as a professor    at the Saratov Conservatory; Pavel Klochkov (18841966) who  was an early Russian recording  artist;  Vladimir  Drucker (18981974) who was a principal trumpet with the Los Angeles Philharmonic; and Mikhail Tabakov (18771956) who became professor  at the Moscow  Conservatory. Several of his  compositions and  etude books are published by International Music Company.

Ivan Berlyn  (1867   11  December 1934) was  an English actor of stage and silent film  whose  career spanned four decades. An experienced and versatile actor, Beryln   played   ...  weird and eccentric character parts' in everything from pantomime to Shakespeare. Early life
He was born  in Kensington in London as Isaac Berlin, the son of Emanuel Berlin (1839-1921) a Jewish mercantile clerk  and a native of  Hamburg who immigrated to  England in 1857, and his wife Amelia  ne Joseph (1836-1915), who married in 1864. In the 1906 edition of the actors' directory The Green Room Book Berlyn  made the spurious  claim that   he had been born as Ivan  Emanuel Julian von Berlin and was descended from an ancient family from Alsace-Lorraine. He  further claimed he had originally planned to join the legal profession but instead decided on a career on the  stage, training at the  London School  of  Elocution (the South  London School  of Elocution  and  Dramatic Art) established by Samuel Brandram. In 1888 as Ivan Berlin  he organized a concert  at the Prince's Hall on Piccadilly in London.  Also as  Ivan  Berlin he is listed in the 1891 Census as  residing at  17 All Saints  Road, Kensington with his parents and his  sisters, Emily and Jenny Berlin and his brother,   Joachim Norman Berlin (1875-1943),  described as the Manager  of the  Chelsea Palace.

Albrecht Drer (; ; ; 21 May 1471   6 April 1528), sometimes spelled  in English as Durer (without an umlaut) or  Duerer, was  a German  painter,  printmaker, and theorist of the German Renaissance. Born in  Nuremberg, Drer established   his  reputation and influence   across Europe in his twenties due to his high-quality woodcut  prints. He was  in  contact with the major Italian artists of  his  time, including Raphael, Giovanni Bellini,  and Leonardo  da Vinci,  and  from 1512  was patronized by Emperor Maximilian I. Drer's vast body of work includes engravings, his preferred technique  in his later prints,  altarpieces, portraits and  self-portraits, watercolours and books. The woodcuts series are more Gothic than the rest of his work. His well-known engravings include the three Meisterstiche (master prints) Knight, Death  and the Devil (1513), Saint Jerome in  his Study (1514), and Melencolia I (1514). His watercolours mark him as one  of  the first European  landscape artists, while  his woodcuts revolutionised the potential  of that medium.

Paul  Howard  Manship (December 24, 1885  January 28, 1966) was an American   sculptor. He consistently created mythological pieces in a classical style, and was a major force in the   Art Deco movement. He is well known for his large public commissions, including the iconic Prometheus in Rockefeller Center and the Celestial Sphere Woodrow Wilson Memorial in Geneva,  Switzerland. He is also  credited for designing  the modern rendition  of New  York City's official seal. Manship  gained notice early in his career  for rejecting the Beaux-Arts architecture movement and preferring linear  compositions with  a flowing simplicity. Additionally, he shared a summer home in Plainfield, New Hampshire, part of the  Cornish Art Colony, with  William Zorach for a  number  of  years.   Other members of the highly social colony  were  also contemporary artists. Manship created his own artist retreat on Cape Ann, developing a 15-acre site  on two former granite  quarries in Lanesville, a   village of  Gloucester, MA.  A local nonprofit, the Manship  Artists Residency +  Studios was established in 2015  to preserve  this  estate as an artist residency program.

Kisses is the fourth studio album by Brazilian singer Anitta, released on April 5, 2019, through  Warner Music Brasil.  It is a trilingual  visual   album, with songs in Portuguese, Spanish and English, and music  videos for each track. It received a Latin Grammy  nomination for Best Urban Music Album. Background
In 2016,  after completing promotion   for her third  studio album Bang, Anitta  began  planning an international career and started releasing a series of collaborations  including singles  with  artists such as   Maluma, Iggy  Azalea and Major Lazer during 2016  and 2017 in order to start the process of  establishing her  career outside of Brazil. The collaboration with Iggy Azalea, "Switch", marked the first time Anitta released a song in which she sings  in English. A single named "Paradinha", which is sung in Spanish, followed in 2017 and became one of Anitta's   biggest hits in Brazil whilst also  charting in  other countries such as Mexico and Portugal. In July, 2017, Billboard announced  Anitta  signed with Shots Studios for management outside   of   Brazil and that  she was working  on an English-language album which would  feature Marshmello, Alesso and Poo  Bear.

Rowan Blanchard (born October 14, 2001) is an American actress and political activist. She was included on a  list of   Time's list of  Most Influential Teens in 2015. She  first became known for starring as Rebecca Wilson  in Spy  Kids: All the  Time  in  the  World (2011),   and had her  breakthrough portraying Riley Matthews on the  Disney Channel series  Girl Meets World  (20142017), both of which earned her Young Artist Award nominations. She  has since had roles as Jackie Geary on  the ABC  sitcom The Goldbergs  (20172018), and Alexandra Cavill  in the TNT series Snowpiercer (2020present). Early life
Blanchard was born in Los Angeles, California, to Elizabeth and Mark  Blanchard-Boulbol, who are yoga instructors. Her paternal grandfather has Armenian, Syrian, Lebanese, and Moroccan  ancestry; whereas her paternal grandmother's   ancestors are from England, Denmark, and Sweden. Her paternal great-grandparents had met  in Aleppo,  present-day Syria.  She was  named after a character in Anne  Rice's The Witching Hour.  Rowan has two younger siblings, Carmen and Shane.

Ivan Paunovi (Serbian Cyrillic:  , born 17 June 1986 in Uice) is a Serbian football midfielder. He signed his first  contract in 2003  with FK Smederevo playing back then in the First League of Serbia and Montenegro. Still young and after not getting any  chance to play in  the  league during that year, he decided to continue his career in  lower league clubs  such as FK Sloga Poega, FK  Vuji Voda and FK Sloboda   Uice. In summer  2006 he  moved to FK  Mladi Radnik and after a good  first  half of the season,  he spent the next  six months  on loan with FK Vodovac playing then in  the 200607 Serbian  SuperLiga. Unfortunately FK Vodovac  ended the  seasons relegated, but Paunovi  impressed and the club signed him and he  will  end  up playing two  more seasons with them. In  2009,  he moved  to FK Srem Sremska Mitrovica and after  six months Romanian  Liga I  club FC Universitatea Craiova signed him. After not  getting many chances he decided to  return  to Serbia and in summer 2010  he signed with FK  Metalac Gornji Milanovac  playing in  the SuperLiga. In winter break of 2010-11 he  was loaned to FK Novi Pazar to help the club to reach its ambitions to end the  season promoted to the SuperLiga for  its first time.

Delhi Public School Barra  is a private school running under the aegis of  the Delhi  Public School Society, New  Delhi in Kanpur in  the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. This school  is affiliated to  the Central Board of Secondary Education  (CBSE), New  Delhi. DPS Barra  is  located in  Barra at Meharban Singh ka Purwa, besides River Pandu (a tributary of River Ganga). Overview
Established in 2010, DPS Barra functions under the leadership  and supervision of   its founder Principal, Mrs. Shilpa Manish. Moreover, DPS Kidwai Nagar  was established at K-Block, Kidwai Nagar in 2011 as a  feeder school  for DPS Barra. DPS Barra, located in   a 14-acre campus is a  co-educational school. The School has of an Administrative Block and an Academic Block. The Academic Block  has a Primary section for classes Play Group  - Class V while the Middle  Section resides   classes  VI -  VIII. The Senior Section consists  of classes IX  X. The School  has an  amphitheater, a multipurpose hall, playground, academic Labs and    a library.  The school also conducts classes for extracurricular activities such as Music,  Dance, Theater, and Fine Arts.

Greenmuseum.org was a nonprofit  online  museum of environmental art. Since its launch  in 2001, greenmuseum.org had become a  source  for information about this global art   movement, which includes  ecoart (or  ecological art), land  art, art in nature and related terms. It was formed by a group  of artists in the San Francisco  Bay Area who were interested in ecology who had observed that a museum  did not exist  that was  dedicated  to   the  history art and ecology. History
The concept  for the museum emerged in 2000 from a San Francisco Bay Area collaborative sculpture   group called Meadowsweet Dairy.  Members of the collective included Sam Bower, Genda Griffith, Henry Corning, Dan Ustin, Alan Leavitt, Tyler Johnson and Alex Tereshkin. These artists recognized the  need for a cultural infrastructure to  support ecological artwork  and artists. Through a series  of meetings, the name  greenmuseum.org was  arrived upon, and the collective applied for non-profit status. The site was launched on  December  21, 2001.

Narasimhan Murali (born in Chennai (Madras)   on 11 August 1946) did his school education in Madras Christian College High School,  graduated in Commerce from Loyola  College, Chennai and  later professionally  qualified as a Chartered Accountant.    Joined the family business of THE HINDU in 1969.      Became General  Manager  in  1977 and  Joint Managing Director in 1995.   In 2006 became Managing Director of THE HINDU and M/s.Kasturi & Sons Limited (Publishers of THE HINDU and other allied publications).  Presently Co-Chairman,  Kasturi & Sons Ltd., Proprietors  of THE HINDU group of publications. Career
Murali was   the managing director and publisher of The  Hindu and Frontline during a career which spanned four decades  of printing and publishing. During his time at The Hindu Group Murali focussed on matters  concerning the  production of  the publications,  procurement  of  newsprint, upgrading  of technology, logistics and management  aspects. Posts held in Newspaper and Media Industry bodies:
President of the  Indian Newspaper  Society (INS) - (198384)  
Chairman, Council of Management, Audit  Bureau of Circulations (ABC) (199697);
Chairman, National Readership   Studies Council (NRSC) (1998-2000);
Chairman, Board of Governors, Advertising Standards Council of India (ASCI) (200304)  ) Elected as first  Board  Member  from   South Asia of IFRA, Darmstadt, Germany (the worlds leading association for media publishing) (1998-2004); Member of the Board  of World Association of Newspapers(WAN),Paris  (200506)
Chairman, Board of  Trustees of Press   Institute  of India  RIND (May 2003-Sept.2010).
Conferred "Distinguished Service  Award" by the Advertising  Club Chennai in 1995 for contribution to Advertising.

Robert Patrick Amell  IV (born April  21, 1988) is a  Canadian actor and producer.  He is best-known  for his roles as  Stephen Jameson on The CW series The Tomorrow  People, Ronnie  Raymond/Firestorm on The  CW series The Flash, Nathan Brown on Upload, Fred  Jones in   the films Scooby-Doo! The Mystery  Begins and Scooby-Doo! Curse of  the Lake Monster, The Hunters as  Paxton Flynn, The DUFF as Wesley Rush, The Babysitter as  Max, and the science fiction film Code 8 as Connor Reed; the latter  of which also  starred his real life  cousin Stephen Amell. He also  appeared on television shows such as Life with Derek,  True Jackson, VP, Unnatural  History,  and  Revenge. Early life
Amell   was born  in Toronto; he is  the son of Jo (ne Burden) and Robert Patrick "Rob" Amell III,  who  work in the  custom  jewelry business. His  first cousin is Arrow  actor Stephen Amell. Along with his sister,  he started modeling and acting in small roles in commercials when he was six years old. At age sixteen,  he began landing roles  in high school plays such  as Louis and Dave and  Fionia, Picasso at  the  Lapin Agile and The Importance  of Being Earnest. His love for acting made   him go to Canadian Studios Acting Academy. He graduated from Lawrence Park  Collegiate Institute in Toronto in 2006. He later pursued his career in acting.

Heather Levi is  an American anthropologist best known for her research in  lucha  libre.  Levi was born in Massachusetts and became an   Assistant professor of Anthropology at Temple University. She received her Bachelor of Arts  degree in Anthropology  from the University of Massachusetts in 1990 and went on  to receive a PhD in Anthropology in 2001 from  New York University. She   currently lives  in Philadelphia.  She  is  currently doing   research on street musicians in  Condesa in Mexico City. Her research mainly focuses on performance  practices, global and  local  contexts,  and the political uses to which  they  are directed. Levi has performed ethnographic field work on lucha libre in Mexico City and the significance it  has in  the Mexican culture.  Not only did she  do ethnographic field work,   but she also trained with a retired lucha libre wrestler and his students. Levi worked with this well respected wrestler for  a year and a half and incorporated this as research into her book The World of Lucha   Libre  This allowed  Levi to view lucha libre as an arena that examined the connections between  ideas of mestizaje, class, gender, aesthetic values, mass mediation, and the state.  This thus led her  to write her  book  The World  of Lucha Libra in which these ideas are  explored. In  a Los Angeles Times interview in 2009  she described lucha libre  created a unique, cross-class "cultural phenomenon" that put  on a  "display of these larger-than-life  heroes but  heroes that everybody...knew  [and] came from their social class."

The Kaya identity is an identity stating that   the total emission level of the greenhouse  gas  carbon dioxide can be expressed as the product of four factors:   human population,   GDP per capita, energy intensity (per unit  of GDP), and carbon intensity (emissions per  unit of energy consumed).  It is  a  concrete form of the more  general I = PAT equation relating factors that determine the level of human  impact on  climate. Although the terms  in the  Kaya identity  would in theory cancel out, it is useful in practice to calculate emissions in terms of more readily available data, namely population, GDP per capita, energy per unit GDP, and emissions per unit energy. It  furthermore highlights the  elements  of the global economy  on which one could act to reduce emissions, notably  the energy intensity  per unit  GDP and the emissions per unit energy. Overview 
The Kaya identity was developed by Japanese  energy economist Yoichi Kaya. It  is the subject of his book Environment,   Energy,  and  Economy: strategies for sustainability co-authored with Keiichi Yokobori as  the output of the Conference on  Global Environment, Energy, and Economic Development (1993 :  Tokyo, Japan).  It is a  mathematically more  consistent variation of Paul  R. Ehrlich & John Holdren's I=PAT formula  that  describes the factors  of environmental impact.Kaya  identity is expressed in the form:

The Club de Berne is   an  intelligence   sharing  forum between the intelligence services  of the  27 states of the European  Union  (EU), Norway and Switzerland, named after  the city of Bern. It is an institution  based on  voluntary exchange of secrets, experience and views  as  well as discussing problems. The Club has  existed since 1971 and has no secretariat and takes no decisions. The Counter  Terrorism Group (CTG)  is an offshoot of the Club and shares terrorism  intelligence. It provides threat assessments  to EU  policy makers and provides a form for expert collaboration.  The Group was  created after 9/11 to further intelligence  sharing cooperation between  European intelligence structures. CTG,  like the Club, is outside  of the EU's  institutions but communicates with them via the participation of the EU Intelligence Analysis  Centre (EU INTCEN)  (a  branch of the European  External Action Service). Although it is outside  the  EU, its presidency rotates inline with that of the EU Council presidency and acts as a formal interface between the  Club de Berne and the EU.
sampled: Thalamus  segmentation plays a critical role in studying various brain  disorders  and understanding functional connectivity.  This paper presents a novel multi-contrast  magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approach for  thalamus segmentation.  Our method utilizes multiple MRI contrasts, including T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted images,  to leverage the complementary  information they provide.   We propose a deep learning framework that combines convolutional neural networks and recurrent  neural networks to achieve accurate and robust thalamus segmentation.  Experimental results on a large dataset demonstrate the superiority  of our approach compared to state-of-the-art  methods and highlight  the  potential  of multi-contrast MRI for improved  thalamus segmentation. Overall, this paper contributes  to advancing the field  of neuroimaging  by presenting a promising technique for thalamus segmentation using multi-contrast MRI.

Power-Law Graph Cuts is an academic  paper that introduces  a novel algorithm for  graph  cuts based on  power-law distributions. The paper presents a new  approach to graph partitioning that leverages the inherent power-law structure of real-world networks. The algorithm is designed to efficiently  handle large-scale  graphs and  is shown to  outperform  existing methods in terms of both runtime  and solution quality. The paper also provides theoretical analysis  and experimental results to support the effectiveness of the  proposed algorithm.  Overall, Power-Law Graph Cuts offers a   valuable  contribution to the field  of graph partitioning and provides a promising solution for various  applications in network analysis and optimization.

This paper presents a novel approach for automatic  3D bi-ventricular segmentation  of cardiac images  using a shape-refined multi-task deep  learning method. The proposed method combines a convolutional   neural network (CNN) with a shape refinement module to accurately segment  the  left and right ventricles  in cardiac  images.  The  CNN is trained on  a  large dataset of annotated cardiac images  to learn the spatial and contextual information necessary for accurate  segmentation. The shape refinement module then refines the initial segmentation results by incorporating shape priors and enforcing smoothness constraints. Experimental results on a publicly available dataset demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms  state-of-the-art methods in terms of  segmentation accuracy and  robustness. The proposed  method  has the potential  to improve  the diagnosis and treatment planning of cardiac diseases by providing  accurate and reliable segmentation  of the ventricles in cardiac images.

This paper investigates the curvature  tensors of  Hermitian manifolds.  The authors provide  a comprehensive analysis of the various  types of curvature tensors that can be defined on  such manifolds, including the Ricci curvature  tensor, the scalar curvature tensor, and the Weyl curvature tensor. The   paper  also explores the relationships between these curvature  tensors and their properties. The authors  present several examples and applications of these curvature tensors in the context of Hermitian  manifolds.  Overall,   this paper contributes to the understanding of the geometric properties of Hermitian manifolds and  provides   a foundation for further research in this area.

This  academic paper presents a novel method  for joint segmentation and localization in videos  and images  by introducing the   concept of foreground clustering. The proposed method first generates a  set of candidate segment proposals using a pre-trained convolutional neural network. Then, a foreground clustering algorithm is applied to group these proposals into coherent foreground objects. This clustering algorithm utilizes  both appearance and motion cues to capture the spatio-temporal coherence of the foreground  objects.  Experimental results   on various  benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of  the  proposed method in  accurately  segmenting  and localizing  foreground objects in videos and  images. This method has  potential applications in computer vision tasks such as video  object segmentation, object tracking, and scene  understanding.

In this paper, we present a multi-contrast magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) approach for segmenting the  thalamus. The  approach is based on the fusion of  T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted  MRI scans. The fusion   is performed  using a three-dimensional (3D) convolutional neural network (CNN). The CNN is  trained on a  large dataset  of  thalamus  segments from  different MRI contrasts. The  resulting model is evaluated on a separate test dataset, and results show that the approach is able to   accurately  segment the  thalamus.  The segmented thalamus can then be used for further analysis, such as brain connectivity analysis.

This paper makes a contribution   to the field of MRI-based brain segmentation by introducing a  multi-contrast approach that leverages the complementary information from different MRI contrasts.  The approach  is evaluated on a large dataset  and  shows promise  for   accurate thalamus segmentation.  The segmented  thalamus can be used for various brain studies, including brain  connectivity analysis.

A multi-contrast MRI approach to thalamus segmentation

Abhishek Kumar1*, Manohar B. Mirmira2, and  Udayakumar M. Kuducheckal3

1Neuroradiology and Nuclear Medicine, Institute of Neurosciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India
2Neuroradiology  and   Nuclear Medicine, Institute of  Medical Sciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India
3Department of Computer Science  and  Engineering,  National Institute of Technology, Tiruchirappalli, India

Keywords: Brain segmentation, Thalamus, Magnetic resonance imaging, Convolutional neural network


Abstract:

Thalamus is  a vital brain structure that connects the  brain to various other parts of the  body.  Magnetic 
resonance  imaging (MRI)  is a  useful tool for studying the thalamus and other brain structures.  In this paper, we present a multi-contrast  MRI approach for segmenting the thalamus. The  approach is based on  the fusion of T1-weighted, T2-weighted,  and diffusion-weighted MRI scans, performed using a three-dimensional  (3D)  convolutional neural network (CNN).   The CNN is trained on   a large  dataset of thalamus segments from different MRI

We introduce power-law graph cuts,  a new algorithmic  framework for electromagnetic  tomography (EMT). EMT reconstructs a conductivity distribution  inside a uniformly-conductive, opaque, and periodic  sample  from boundary measurements of electric  fields.  The classical approach to EMT  reconstruction is based on the Kirchhoff approximation (KA), in  which the conductivity is parameterized by a finite number  of parameters, and the inverse problem is solved as a  nonlinear optimization problem. The  KA performs poorly when the parameterized conductivity  distorts  significantly the internal electric fields.  We show that power-law graph cuts,   a novel convex optimization approach,  are capable of recovering the true  conductivity distribution accurately  even in the presence of significant distortion.

Recent works have  shown that Deep Learning (DL) methods can be  used for myocardial segmentation, however, most of  these methods focus on the  left ventricle (LV) only.  In this work,  we present  a fully  automatic bi-ventricular segmentation approach based on a Shape-Refined Multi-Task  Deep Learning (SRMTDL) framework. Our approach incorporates prior  knowledge of  the global shape of  the left ventricle  and the right ventricle, and models the  complex ventricle-atrium relationship in the cardiac  structure. Specifically, we propagate the  mesh-based shape prior in the volumetric space using  a Shape  Refinement Network   (SRN), and combine   it  with a Multi-Task  Deep Learning (MTDL) framework to simultaneously segment the left and right ventricles and  the left and right atria. We evaluated our approach on 320 cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) datasets from the  2017 Cardiac bundling challenge (CBC), and achieved a mean Inter-User  Agreement  (IUA) of 0.829 and a Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) of 0.837 on the LV, and a mean IUA of 0.842  and DSC  of  0.839 on  the RV.

In this short   note we calculate the curvature tensors of a Hermitian manifold whose first Chern class  is a  positive integer  multiple of  the canonical class.  This generalizes a result of Sato on  the curvature of compact Hermitian manifolds.

We present a novel approach for joint  segmentation and localization  of objects in videos and images. Our method exploits  the spatial  coherence of objects in  image and video frames for jointly optimizing object segments and  their respective bounding boxes.  Towards this end, we introduce  an energy function that tightly integrates  a segmentation  term, based on a  variation of the popular GrabCut  algorithm, and a localization  term, based on a new objectness measure that we introduce  for  this  purpose.  To efficiently optimize the energy function, we propose a novel foreground clustering  technique, allowing us  to  deal  with  sparse, irregular object pixel  assignments, while providing for  simultaneous estimation of object segments and bounding boxes. In order to  assess our method's performance, we introduce a new fully-automatic evaluation metric that gauges localization  accuracy, as compared to ground truth  object bounding boxes. Our method achieves state-of-the-art performance  on the  VOC 2012 segmentation benchmark, considerably improving  over the previous  best method on this dataset, while running  at nearly real-time speed. Furthermore, we show that our foreground clustering technique, when applied to other recent joint segmentation  and  localization methods, improves their   performance as well, thus making our method a  strong baseline for future  research.

In this paper, we present  "UNet++," an improved version of the popular  U-Net architecture for medical image  segmentation. U-Net is a convolutional neural network (CNN) that has shown   promising results in various medical image segmentation tasks. However, it  can  be challenging to train U-Net on certain   datasets due to its fully connected structure, which  can  lead to overfitting and poor  generalization performance. To address these  issues, we propose a nested U-Net architecture that incorporates  a series of dilated   convolutions and  residual connections to  improve  the model's  performance.  Our proposed architecture is easy to train and generalize, and we demonstrate its effectiveness on three different medical image segmentation datasets, achieving state-of-the-art  performance  in two of them. We believe that our proposed architecture will  serve as a strong foundation for future research in medical   image segmentation.

Graph cuts are an effective and efficient algorithmic technique used to partition graphs   into  two subgraphs while minimizing the cut size. In  this paper, we  explore  the use of power laws to optimize the graph cut process. We propose a  new algorithm that utilizes power laws to determine the optimal cut  size, resulting in improved performance over  traditional graph cuts. Our  experimental  results demonstrate that our proposed algorithm  achieves significant  speedup   and improved cut quality compared to existing techniques. This work has implications for  various applications  such as image segmentation, mesh segmentation,  and social network analysis.

Here is an abstract for the academic paper "A Statistical Mechanical Approach to Protein Aggregation":

Protein  aggregation  is a complex process that involves  the formation of larger protein  assemblies from smaller, individual proteins. It is a common feature of many diseases, including neurodegenerative disorders  such as  Alzheimer's   and Parkinson's. In this paper,  we  develop a statistical mechanical approach to protein aggregation, based on the idea that protein aggregation is a thermodynamically  favorable process. We  use a simple model  system to study the  aggregation of a  small  protein,  and we find that our approach is  able to accurately predict the  aggregation behavior of  the protein.  Our results suggest that protein aggregation is a thermodynamically driven  process, and that our approach can be used to study  the aggregation of  proteins in  a variety of  diseases.

This  paper shows that the category of determinantal  varieties  admits a morphism to the category of singular  varieties that preserves limits and is  an isomorphism on the level of sets. This extends a result of M.  Pun  and T. Peternell for rational singularities to  an arbitrary characteristic.

The abstract for the  academic paper titled "RA-UNet: A hybrid deep  attention-aware  network  to extract  liver and tumor  in CT scans" could be:

This paper  proposes a hybrid deep attention-aware network (RA-UNet) for the extraction of liver and tumor in CT scans. The  network combines   the strengths of a UNet-based architecture and a attention-based   mechanism  to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the extraction process.   The RA-UNet utilizes a series of  convolutional layers and attention mechanisms to capture  the  spatial and contextual  information  in the CT scans. The proposed network was evaluated on a public dataset and achieved state-of-the-art performance in  terms of accuracy and efficiency. The results  demonstrate the effectiveness of the  proposed approach in  extracting liver and tumor in CT scans.

Liquid samples are an  important part  of medical tests. Recently, it  has been shown that large-scale deep convolutional neural  networks can significantly improve the  performance in predicting  the  shape and contour of  microfluid.  The goal of this paper  is to apply these techniques to image segmentation and prediction  of liquid samples. Our approach has two main  components:   image segmentation and prediction  of relations between   features. In addition, we  study the performance of   two machine learning techniques, the nearest neighbor metric and the MLE algorithm.

The methods presented in the paper are also part of a research project by the  Medical  School at the University.

The paper will be presented at ICML 2015 in Tokyo. You  can see  the  slides and the  corresponding code here as  they will be published at  arXiv shortly.

Comments welcome and the abstract will be updated when available.

More pictures:

A   new study shows  that B-COSFIRE filters, which  map noise levels on an object's surface to its depth in two dimensions, represent in a similar fashion lines on a surface. For example, when the spatial resolution of  the image is large, a  B-COSFIRE  filter  can be  used to distinguish between two  surfaces, such as the image on the right (from an article by Zoltn Istvn, published in the  journal Scientific Reports).  Credit: Zoltn Istvn/Shutterstock.com. A  new study shows that B-COSFIRE (B-COSFIRE-enhanced spectral imaging by line-source  Faint extinction  + High  noise index), which can map noise levels on an  object's surface  to its   depth in two dimensions, represents in a similar fashion lines on a  surface. This new  technique, which we demonstrate  on a range  of images, represents not only in a  comparable manner  lines    on an object's surface, but also any object that is  detected to be  a particular size.  These methods will lead to improved applications in mapping the physical and geological structures in image data at sub-exposure levels. This  is the second article in the  series "Delineation   of line patterns in images using B-COSFIRE filters" where  we  have analyzed the accuracy of B-COSFIRE (see our previous article about this).   More specifically, we   show that not merely  does B-COSFIRE-enhanced  spectral imaging by line source Faint extinction + High  noise index provide good color discrimination  when the spatial resolution is very large (which includes digital cameras), but  we can also discriminate between two objects that are  detected to be   the same size, such as those shown in  the image on the right.

A  simple  method based  on partial derivatives with respect to the parameters , t and d for variational Bayes estimation is evaluated in this work.  In this approach  a video is represented as an object sequence, where i  j refers  to  position or rotation of one  image element j at time t, along line  ij (vertical) of  frames corresponding to frames  with coordinates specified  by i i = jj   +   [t/2]  and  i  denotes the prior expectation parameter  for image element j in the current  frame. By integrating such differential equations over  both horizontal and  vertical planes with respect to the interval [3, 6],  j (t) can be used to compute the gradient  vector, which can then be used in variational bayesian  inference for  image segmenting.  Hereby, we refer to two features : (i) a continuous property called distance between objects relative to the video itself; and (ii) a discrete property known  as feature vectors  and used as weights in  the regression algorithm. Finally,   to determine the number  of steps  required  to obtain reliable results, several empirical tests are carried out in   conjunction with numerical examples.

The purpose of this  study was to  investigate brain segmentation potentials  during CUSUM scanning using high resolution computed  tomography (HRCT) and  contrast MRI in a patient  cohort  with hippocampal damage induced by  stroke, with  T1 weighted imaging data.  Three groups,    diagnosed as having  early or late anterior temporal lobe (ATL) lesions  at  baseline were  exposed to two scan sessions separated 50 days apart: One session without a  scan, one with an echo-planar imaging (EPI) cusum tube, one consisting of a  full head CT  scan only with the help  of an artificial brain.  During both scans sessions T1 weighted images could be acquired  in  order to determine regions  potentially contributing to  normal tissue preservation after traumatic insult and the  number  and location of those regions were compared between the groups that could   have different injury  locations on examination. This  methodology should pave the path toward the  development  of high dynamic range nonlinear cusums such as SPM2/3s with low  signal  attenuation, low background noise and small spatial  volume (SV). We  suggest  that brain segments produced by SPM2/3 may aid cognitive neuroscience investigation such as determining whether or not certain regions are associated  prior  to any pathological insult such as stroke in patients suffering from hippocampal loss induced by cortical lesion.

In this  paper we present a method for automated thalamus segmentation in MRI using  a multi-contrast approach. We combine T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and T2  FLAIR  images in a single registration and segmentation  framework using a combination of atlas-based  and model-based methods. We evaluate our method on a  dataset of 30  subjects, and compare  our results to those of a  state-of-the-art thalamus segmentation method. Our results  show  that our method outperforms the  state-of-the-art in terms of accuracy,  while being significantly faster.

We propose  a new method for finding  graph cuts which  is based on the power-law degree distribution of the graph. Our  method is able to find graph  cuts  which are  significantly better than those found  by other methods, while being much faster.

In this  paper, we propose a novel deep learning approach for automatic 3D bi-ventricular segmentation of  cardiac images. Our  approach   is based on a shape-refined multi-task deep learning framework, which consists of two sub-networks: a  shape network and a segmentation network. The shape   network is used to generate a shape prior for the   segmentation  network. The segmentation network is then trained to segment   the left ventricle (LV) and right ventricle (RV) simultaneously, using the   shape prior  from the shape  network.  We evaluated our  approach on the ACDC challenge dataset, and  the results showed that our  approach outperformed the state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

In this paper, we  study the curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds. We  prove that the  curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds satisfy   certain identities  which are generalizations of  the well-known  identities satisfied by the curvature  tensors of Riemannian manifolds. As  a consequence, we obtain a characterization of the  curvature tensors of Hermitian manifolds in terms of the  Ricci tensor and the scalar curvature.

With the advent of  powerful Deep  Neural  Networks (DNNs),  semantic segmentation of images  and  videos has seen significant improvement in recent   years. However,   most existing methods are  limited to segmenting  a single object category in an image or video. In this    paper, we propose a novel approach to joint segmentation and  localization of multiple object categories  in images and videos. Our method is based on a new method  for foreground clustering, which we  call foregroundness-aware clustering. This method is able to cluster foreground objects in an image or   video, while  also accounting for their  spatial layout. We then use the clustered foreground  objects to train a DNN for joint  segmentation and localization. We evaluate our method on the challenging Youtube-Objects dataset, and show that  it outperforms the state-of-the-art methods for joint segmentation and localization.

This paper presents a novel approach for thalamus  segmentation using  multi-contrast Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). The  focus of the study   is to enhance the accuracy,  efficiency, and effectiveness of thalamus identification and  volumetric analysis in the human brain via MRI. The method utilized  a combination of T1-weighted,  T2-weighted, and diffusion-weighted contrasts to differentiate between thalamus and non-thalamus  structures. Experimental results indicate that our  multi-contrast   MRI approach significantly improves thalamus segmentation compared to  traditional single-contrast  methods, promising  potential applications in studying various  neurological conditions that impact the thalamus.

This paper presents an  in-depth study on Power-Law Graph Cuts,  a novel approach  to partitioning large-scale graphs.  The  study explores  the theoretical underpinnings  of the power-law distribution in graph cuts and  its implications for network analysis. The  paper also introduces an  efficient algorithm for  computing power-law graph cuts, demonstrating its effectiveness  through extensive experiments on various real-world datasets. The results show that  power-law graph  cuts    can provide more accurate  and meaningful  partitions than traditional methods, especially for  graphs with skewed degree distributions. This research opens up new possibilities for analyzing and understanding complex networks  in various fields, including social networks, web graphs, and biological networks.

This paper presents an innovative deep  learning approach  for automatic  3D bi-ventricular segmentation  of cardiac images. The proposed method leverages a  multi-task learning framework that  simultaneously  performs segmentation and shape regression  tasks, thereby improving  the  accuracy and robustness of the segmentation  results. The model is trained on a large  dataset of cardiac images, and its performance is evaluated against manual segmentations by expert radiologists. The results demonstrate  that  the proposed approach outperforms existing methods in terms  of  both segmentation accuracy and computational efficiency. This research has significant  implications  for the development of automated tools  for cardiac image analysis, potentially improving the diagnosis and treatment  of heart  diseases.

This  paper  delves into the intricate study of curvature  tensors of Hermitian manifolds. It provides  a comprehensive analysis of  the   properties and characteristics of these tensors,  focusing on their role in the geometry and topology of Hermitian manifolds.  The paper also  explores the relationship between curvature tensors and other geometric entities,  such as  the Ricci tensor and the scalar curvature. The results obtained contribute to the understanding of the geometric structure of Hermitian manifolds and  have potential  applications in differential geometry, theoretical physics, and  other related fields. The paper  concludes with   a  discussion on the implications of the findings  and suggestions for future research.

This  paper addresses the task of joint segmentation and localization in both  videos   and images by introducing a  novel method, 'Foreground Clustering'. The  method  oversees identifying and clustering foreground  pixels  that share similar  object-level properties while discerning them  from the background. The authors articulate a  new algorithm that assimilates both spatial and temporal  cues, simultaneously localizing and  segmenting foreground objects efficiently. It surpasses traditional  methods, which perform these  tasks separately,  improving both accuracy and speed. The presented experimental results show that this Foreground Clustering  method outperforms existing  state-of-the-art techniques on several benchmark datasets, leading to more  precise and efficient segmentation and localization in videos and  images.

Abstract:

Left  atrial  segmentation from 3D gadolinium  enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)  is a  crucial  step in diagnosing and managing cardiac arrhythmias. However,  manual segmentation  of the left atrium can be time-consuming and observer-dependent,  leading to  variability in clinical decision-making.  In  this study, we propose a deep learning approach using dilated convolutional neural  networks  (DCNNs) for automated left atrial segmentation  in 3D gadolinium enhanced-MRI. Our proposed  method utilizes  a combination of spatial pyramid  pooling  and multi-scale features fusion to improve feature extraction and enhance performance. We evaluated our method on  a dataset of 100 patients  and compared it with traditional CNNs and  U-Net architectures. The  results show that  DCNNs outperformed both traditional CNNs  and U-Nets  in terms of segmentation accuracy, achieving an  average Dice similarity coefficient of 86.5%. Additionally, we  observed that DCNNs were more robust to variations  in heart   rate and image quality compared to other methods. These findings suggest  that DCNNs are a promising tool for accurate  and efficient  left atrial segmentation in 3D gadolinium enhanced-MRI, which  could potentially improve the consistency and efficiency of clinical decision-making in cardiology.

In this paper, we propose a novel approach to improve the performance of  fully  convolutional networks (FCNs) by learning what to attend to in images. Our approach, called AttentionBoost, leverages the strengths of recent attention mechanisms to  boost the performance  of FCNs  in  various  computer vision tasks.

Existing attention  mechanisms have shown promising results in natural language processing and image captioning,  but they have limitations when applied to image classification and object detection tasks. Specifically, these mechanisms are designed to focus  on specific parts of an image, but they often struggle to identify  the most relevant regions when dealing with   complex images or multiple objects.

AttentionBoost addresses this issue by introducing  a novel attention module that  learns to attend to the  most discriminative  regions of an image. Our module is designed to be lightweight and can  be easily integrated  into existing FCN architectures. We  evaluate  AttentionBoost on several benchmark datasets, including CIFAR-10,  CIFAR-100,  and PASCAL VOC.

The key contribution of  this paper is the  introduction of a novel attention mechanism that learns to attend to the most   discriminative regions  of an image,  leading to improved  performance in  image classification  and object detection tasks. Our approach  outperforms existing  attention mechanisms and  achieves state-of-the-art results on several benchmarks.

The paper  is organized as follows: In section 2, we  review  related work  on  attention mechanisms and their applications  in  computer vision. In section 3, we introduce the AttentionBoost module and its architecture.  In section  4,  we  describe the experimental setup and the datasets used for  evaluation. In section  5, we present the results of our experiments and  compare AttentionBoost with existing attention mechanisms. Finally,  in section 6,  we conclude the  paper and discuss future directions  for improving AttentionBoost.

Overall, AttentionBoost  offers a promising approach to improving the  performance of  FCNs  in various  computer vision tasks,  and  we believe it has the potential  to be widely adopted  in the field.

This paper proposes a  new approach to modeling spatial data using dynamic spatial autoregressive (SAR)  models that account for both autoregressive and heteroskedastic disturbances. The  proposed model, called the  dynamic SAR(p,d,q) model, extends  the traditional SAR  model by incorporating time-varying  parameters  and heteroskedastic disturbances, which   allows for a more flexible and realistic representation of  spatial data. The model is estimated using  a Bayesian approach,  which allows for the incorporation of prior information and provides a natural way to handle model  uncertainty. The paper also  discusses the use of informative prior  distributions and provides guidance on how to choose appropriate priors.  The  model is applied  to a real-world dataset  and the  results show  that it outperforms traditional SAR models in terms of forecast accuracy and ability to capture spatial patterns.  The paper concludes  by discussing the contributions and limitations of    the proposed model and suggesting directions  for  future research.

Keywords:  spatial data, dynamic spatial   autoregressive models, heteroskedastic disturbances, Bayesian estimation, informative priors.

In this paper,  we investigate homotopy invariants of   combings  of 3-manifolds. A combing of  a  3-manifold is a way of decomposing it into smaller  pieces,  called teeth, that are glued together along their boundaries in a specific  way. We  focus on homotopy invariants  of combings,  which  are  properties  that remain unchanged under continuous deformations of the combing.

We first establish  a framework for   studying  homotopy  invariants of combings by defining a notion of homotopy between combings and introducing a category whose objects  are combings and whose morphisms are homotopy classes  of combings. We then prove that this  category is triangulated,  meaning that it has well-defined  notions of kernels and cokernels,   and that these can be used to define homology and cohomology groups of combings.

Next, we explore various homotopy invariants of  combings, including the number of teeth, the total space  of the combing,  and the fundamental group of the  complement of the teeth. We show that all of  these  invariants  can   be computed  using the above-mentioned homology and cohomology groups.

In particular, we prove that the number of teeth is equal to the dimension of the kernel of  a certain map from the homology group  of  the 3-manifold to its  cohomology group, while  the total space of the combing can be identified with the cokernel of another map between these groups. Finally, we  show that the fundamental  group of the complement  of the teeth can be realized as a quotient of the  fundamental group of  the 3-manifold modulo a certain normal subgroup that encodes information about the combinatorics of the   combing.

Our results provide   a new perspective on the study of 3-manifolds and their decompositions, and they have  important implications for  the understanding of topological   and  geometric structure of  these  spaces. They also demonstrate the  power of our proposed approach to the study of homotopy invariants  of combings, and pave the way for further  investigations in this area.

> In  this work, we propose an automatic prostate segmentation method based  on fine-grained recurrent neural networks (RNN). We first extract features  using a  convolutional neural  network (CNN) and then use RNN to learn the spatial context information between adjacent pixels. To  improve the performance  of our  model,  we introduce two  novel strategies into our framework. Firstly, we design a multi-scale feature fusion strategy that can effectively  fuse  different scale features  extracted by CNN. Secondly, we adopt a progressive training scheme which  gradually increases   the difficulty  level during  the  training  process. Experimental results show that our proposed approach achieves state-of-the-art performance  compared with other methods.

> In this work, we propose an automatic method to segment  brain tumors  in perfusion MRI scans using Cumulative Sum (CUSUM)  filtering and    machine learning techniques.  We use a combination  of intensity-based  features extracted from the original images as well  as texture descriptors  computed by applying Gabor filters at different scales and orientations. These features are used to train Support Vector Machines (SVMs),  which classify each voxel into one of   three classes:  normal  tissue,  edema or necrosis. Our results show that our proposed  approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods such as fuzzy c-means clustering and level set evolution.

The abstract for the academic paper titled   "Sigma Point Belief Propagation" is as follows:

Title:    Sigma Point Belief Propagation

Author: John Doe

Abstract: This paper presents a  new approach to  belief propagation  in Bayesian networks, based on the sigma point method. The sigma point method is a  technique used in stochastic process  control to estimate the state  of the process, and it can be extended  to  belief propagation  in Bayesian networks by using sigma points to represent the state of the  network.

The proposed approach uses sigma points to initialize the belief distribution  and  then iteratively updates the belief distribution  using Bayesian  rule and the sigma point method. The paper also presents a  new algorithm for computing the probability of the  next  sigma  point using Bayesian update rule  and   the sigma point method.

The proposed approach is shown to be  effective in  estimating the  posterior  probability of  the network parameters in a Bayesian  model,  as  well as in  computing the  likelihood of the network parameters given new data. The paper concludes with a comparison with existing belief propagation methods, and the  results show that the proposed method is computationally efficient and accurate.

The  paper presents  an automatic image  pixel clustering   algorithm based  on the Mussels  Wandering Optimization (MWO) algorithm. The proposed algorithm is designed to efficiently  cluster pixels in an image based on their  similarity in color and intensity. The MWO algorithm is used  to optimize the clustering process by iteratively adjusting the  cluster centers until  convergence is achieved. The algorithm is tested   on a variety of images  and compared  to other clustering algorithms. The results show that  the proposed algorithm is effective in clustering pixels in an image  and is more efficient than other clustering algorithms.

The  paper  presents a novel method for fast and accurate 3D medical image segmentation using data-swapping. The proposed method involves swapping  the data  from the  source image with the target image to improve the segmentation accuracy. The data-swapping  process is performed using a deep learning-based approach that involves   training a neural network to  predict the segmentation labels  of the target image  based on the source  image.  The proposed method is evaluated  on a  large  dataset of 3D medical images and compared with state-of-the-art methods.  The results show that the proposed method achieves faster and more accurate segmentation than  the  existing methods. The paper concludes that the data-swapping  method is a promising  approach for improving the accuracy and speed of  3D  medical  image segmentation.

We study a problem of inverse solving a linear system of equations with  additive noise. This  problem  occurs in various imaging fields with different constraints and additional goals, for instance,  image reconstruction in positron  emission tomography (PET) and computer tomography (CT). In this paper,  we propose  a novel   algorithm  that  combines the advantage of iterative and non-iterative algorithms as well as the benefits  of using a deep neural network and a generative model. In every iteration, we simultaneously  perform image reconstruction, regularization, denoising, and a gradient descent update of the network parameters.  We  show that it is beneficial to train  our network in an end-to-end fashion with noisy  ground-truth data and it leads to better results as  compared to using clean data, particularly in the case of low-dose PET. Moreover, the  method achieves  competitive performance compared  to the iterative algorithms.

Graphs are ubiquitous in science  and  engineering, with applications ranging across social networks to molecular  structures; however their   analysis has been limited by computational complexity issues  that have prevented large-scale graph  processing on  modern  supercomputers or clusters [1].  The advent of high performance computing (HPC) systems based upon manycore processors such as GPU's offers an opportunity not only improve scalability   but also enable  new algorithms which exploit parallelism at  multiple levels within graphs themselves - including  vertex-, edge-(sub-)graph level operations  along side traditional matrix algebra primitives  like addition/multiplication etc.. This work presents mathematical foundations behind these concepts using linear  algebraic  techniques developed  over past decades combined together into  one unified framework  called 'Linear Algebraic Programming' where each operation corresponds directly back onto some underlying  algorithm implementation(e).g., sparse  matrices via CSR format  while dense ones  use  DAG representation instead."

The  purpose of this research paper is to propose a method for improving state-of-the-art  image segmentation methods  for biomedical images. They  do this by improving upon Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) in order  to improve  results with regards to accuracy and speed.    We have previously shown that state-of-the-art  semantic segmentation  results outperform  other methods for brain tumor segmentation and are competitive with expert annotator measurements.  However, these networks are not fully convolutional in nature,  meaning they may not be  well-suited for fast applications. One of  the most significant   advantages  of  the fully convolutional network is that it is very fast and computationally  efficient  in that it does not need to have a pool   layer and  fully  connected layers. Another reason is that fully convolutional networks are trainable end-to-end and  they  provide full  segmentation mask output with  one pass per image at run-time, which  is advantageous if time in one of the critical resources for biomedical image analysis. The  paper shows through various experiments that  full networks with quantized  weights and activations  are significantly better than  a network with  floating-point (32-bit) weights and activations. For example, quantizing weights and activations reduce  memory  requirements  by 4x, memory requirements by 8x, and runtime by 3-30x, depending on input size and   computational complexity  of each image. The paper  also includes a  discussion of the performance impact of different weight  and activation bit-depth trade-offs. The results of the experiments show that  the network architecture proposed here for biomedical segmentation  is significantly  faster than existing  fully convolutional biomedical segmentation  networks, while maintaining accuracy.

This study investigates the use   of  dilated convolutions  in  neural networks for left atrial segmentation in three-dimensional gadolinium enhanced-magnetic resonance imaging (3D GE-MRI). The aim  is to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the segmentation process. We  trained a deep learning model   using 2D and 3D  convolutional layers with different  dilation rates, and evaluated its performance  on a dataset of 30 patients. Our results show  that incorporating dilated convolutions significantly improves the dice similarity  coefficient compared to models without dilated convolutions. Additionally, we  found that increasing the  dilation rate  leads to better segmentation  outcomes. Overall, our approach  provides an effective solution for left atrial segmentation in  3D GE-MRI utilizing state-of-the-art  network  architectures.

AttentionBoost is  a   method  that  enhances fully convolutional networks by learning what to attend to  in an image. It uses a boosting approach to iteratively refine the  network's attention map, leading to improved performance on  various computer vision tasks. By  incorporating attention mechanisms  into the  network, AttentionBoost allows for more efficient and accurate processing of  visual information, making  it a valuable tool for a range of applications in computer vision.

This research examines the relationship between supersymmetry and the topological   properties of eigenfunctions in the context of  the  planar quantum pendulum. By analyzing the  Schrdinger equation  via semiclassical methods, we reveal that a hidden symmetry manifests itself through specific topologial  structures within the wave  functions associated with discrete energy levels. The Shepherdess and the Chimney Sweep  is a heartwarming tale that follows the lives of two porcelain figurines, a shepherdess  and a chimney sweep, who come  to life  and embark on a  series of adventures. The story begins  when the two  figurines are placed on a mantelpiece in  a cozy cottage. As  the days go by, they develop a  deep bond and  dream of a life beyond their stationary existence.  One  night,  a gust of  wind blows open  the window, and the shepherdess  and  the  chimney  sweep find themselves outside,  free to explore the   world. They  encounter various  challenges and meet a cast  of colorful  characters, including a wise old dog  and  a  mischievous cat. Along their journey, they learn valuable lessons about  love, friendship, and the importance of staying true to oneself. As they  navigate  through the bustling  city  and the serene countryside, the shepherdess and  the chimney  sweep face numerous obstacles that test their courage and resilience.  Ultimately, they  discover that  their true purpose is to bring joy and happiness to  those they encounter. With their unwavering determination and unwavering love for each other, the shepherdess  and the chimney sweep overcome adversity and find their way back to  the cottage, forever changed by their extraordinary experiences.  This enchanting tale is a testament to  the power of love and the transformative nature of adventure.

The novel "Irish  Thoroughbred" follows  the story of  Adelia Cunnane, a young  Irish woman who moves to America to start a new life. Adelia finds herself  working on a horse  farm owned by Travis Grant,  a wealthy and handsome horse breeder. Despite their initial differences,  Adelia and Travis are drawn to each other and  soon  develop a deep connection. As their  relationship  grows, Adelia becomes more involved in the world of  horse racing and  learns about  the  intricacies of breeding  and  training thoroughbreds. However, their love is tested when Adelia's past catches   up with her, threatening to tear them apart.  With determination and resilience, Adelia and   Travis must confront their fears and fight for their love against all odds. Set against the  backdrop of the picturesque Irish  countryside and the vibrant horse racing  industry,  "Irish Thoroughbred" is a  captivating tale of love, passion, and the pursuit of dreams.

"To Live Forever" is a  captivating novel that follows the journey of protagonist  Emma Robinson, a young woman who  becomes fascinated with the idea of defying death and achieving immortality. The story begins in a futuristic society where advancements in technology and medicine   have made it possible to extend one's lifespan significantly. Emma, haunted  by the loss of  her parents at  an early age, becomes convinced that living forever is the key to ultimate   happiness  and is  determined to find   a way to  achieve it.

Driven by her obsession,  Emma embarks on a  quest to unravel the mysteries surrounding immortality. She becomes deeply engrossed in studying ancient texts, searching for elixirs of  youth, and  travelling to remote places in search of mythical creatures said to possess  eternal life. Along her journey, Emma encounters various characters, each with their own beliefs and desires regarding  immortality. These encounters  force her to question her own motives and reconsider her definition  of true happiness.

As Emma digs deeper  into  her research, she stumbles upon a   secret society known as The Immortalists. The group  claims to have discovered a groundbreaking  scientific breakthrough that would enable their  members to live forever. Intrigued, Emma is eager to  join  their ranks, believing this to be her  ticket to everlasting  life. However, as she delves further into  the  society's practices, Emma  starts to question the  ethical  implications and consequences of achieving immortality. She begins to  wonder  if there is a  price too great to pay for eternal life.

As her doubts grow, Emma becomes entangled in a dangerous world   of deception and  manipulation.  She uncovers a dark side to   the  Immortalists' agenda, where power and   greed seem to take precedence over  the pursuit of  knowledge and  happiness. Betrayed and disillusioned, Emma must find a way to  expose the truth  before it's too late. Along the  way, she learns valuable  lessons about the importance of cherishing the limited time  we have and the beauty of embracing  mortality.

"To Live Forever"  is a thought-provoking and thrilling  tale that explores the age-old desire for immortality. It delves into themes of mortality, the ethics of  manipulating  life and  death, and  the  meaning of  true happiness. With its engaging plot and well-developed characters, this novel leaves readers questioning  their  own beliefs  about  life, death, and the  pursuit of  eternal   youth.

"Look Me in the Eye" is  a gripping novel that explores the intricacies  of relationships   and  the power of human connection. The  story follows two main  characters, Emily and  Adam, whose lives collide in unexpected ways. Emily,  a driven and successful lawyer, is struggling   to find meaning  in her  life  and confronts her own  vulnerability. Adam, on the other hand, is an introverted artist with  a troubled past who has lost faith in humanity. 

When a chance  encounter brings  them together, Emily and Adam form  an unlikely bond that  transcends their differences. As they navigate the complexities of their relationship, they find solace  and  understanding in one another. Together, they  dive  into  deep conversations about love,  loss,  and  the fragility of happiness.

However, their  journey is not without obstacles. As Emily and Adam grow closer,  they are faced with their own insecurities  and  past traumas that threaten to tear them apart. Each must confront their own inner demons and learn to trust  not  only each other but also themselves.

Throughout the novel,  the characters' emotional depth and personal  growth are  beautifully portrayed. As they navigate the  ups and downs of their relationship, they  begin to discover that true connection lies in embracing vulnerability and being seen for  who they truly are. With a  cast of  supporting characters who add  depth and  richness to the story, "Look  Me in the Eye" is  a poignant exploration   of love, self-discovery, and the power of human connection.

"The Education of Robert Nifkin" follows the coming-of-age journey  of  seventeen-year-old Robert   Nifkin,  a self-proclaimed outcast, as he navigates the  treacherous  waters of  high school in a  small, conservative town  in the late 1950s. With  a  reputation as a troublemaker and a  penchant for questioning authority,  Robert finds himself at  odds  with the traditional values  and stifling conformity  that permeate his community. 

As Robert  grapples with his own identity and  struggles to find his place in the  world, he finds solace and inspiration  in his eclectic group  of friends  who share his outsider status. Together, they challenge the restrictions and  prejudice imposed by their narrow-minded peers and the conservative adults in their lives. 

Throughout  the novel, Robert's  rebellious spirit and thirst for knowledge lead him down a path of self-discovery. He befriends unconventional teachers who  introduce him  to countercultural ideas and writings that broaden  his horizons   and  ignite a passion  for social justice. As his understanding of the world expands, Robert becomes  increasingly determined to challenge the status  quo  and fight for a more egalitarian society.

As Robert's senior year progresses, he finds himself caught between the conflicting expectations of his family, friends, and the  wider world  he  has   come to embrace. Along the way, he experiences the pain of unrequited love and confronts the consequences  of his actions, ultimately learning   valuable lessons about forgiveness, empathy, and personal growth.

"The Education of Robert Nifkin" is an  insightful and captivating  novel  that explores universal themes of identity, rebellion, and  the pursuit  of knowledge. Set against the backdrop of a   changing society,  this coming-of-age story offers  a powerful and inspiring narrative that will resonate with readers of  all ages.

Richard wants  to leave behind the gloomy London  winter and go on a quest to reinvent himself. He finds a seemingly perfect  solution  when he is offered a job in Paris. It's unfortunate that the  offer comes from his  worst boss ever,  Stephen Sparrow, who is narcissistic, hypocritical, and an all-around unpleasant person. Even more unfortunate is that  Stephen wants  Richard to move  to  Paris  immediately and  help his estranged son,  Sebastian, sell his failing apartment building.

Richard hopes to improve his situation by pursuing his  office  crush, Isabelle. He also makes a more instantaneous connection  with Gabrielle, one of Sebastian's tenants. As he adjusts to his new home across  the Channel, Richard finds that the French aren't  as enamored with him as he is with  them.  In fact,   very few people  seem to like him  at all. Meanwhile, Stephen is pressuring Richard to sell the building quickly so he can  collect his substantial inheritance. Anxious to please, Richard butts  heads with Gabrielle and  her fellow tenants, who  refuse to leave their   beloved home.  When Richard sees  how determined the   Frenchies are to  fight for their building, he begins to admire themand suddenly  his year   in France  doesn't seem so terrible after all.

Irish  Thoroughbred is a 1944  novel by Northern Irish novelist Jennifer Johnston. It was her  first novel and was  written while she was  still  an actress in the Belfast Theatre Group. It is set in Belfast amid the  Luftwaffe bombings of the city in 1941.

The   novel   tells the story  of two friends, Eileen and Sarah, whose lives are shaped by their class  differences. Sarah comes from a wealthy family and is educated in  England, while Eileen is a factory worker in Belfast. Despite their  differences, the two women become friends as  teenagers and remain  close throughout their lives. But their class  differences  eventually drive them  apart.

The novel also follows the life of Charlie, a boy from  a  poor family who is educated at Oxford University and becomes a successful lawyer. He falls in love with Sarah, but she rejects him because of his working-class  background.  This rejection leads to Charlie's suicide, which  shatters Sarah's  faith  in her social  standing.

As the Luftwaffe's bombings continue, Eileen's factory  is destroyed, and   she  moves in with Sarah,  who has recently  married a wealthy  businessman. The two   women's relationship is tested  as Sarah's husband becomes increasingly abusive. Sarah eventually leaves her  husband and moves to England, while Eileen remains in Belfast  and continues to work in  the factory.

The novel follows the two women's lives  as  they  struggle to survive and find happiness in the face of  their class differences and the ongoing   violence of  the Luftwaffe bombings.

To Live Forever is a 2007 novel by Ernest Hemingway's grandson, Sen Hemingway. It was published by Bloomsbury Publishing.

The   novel follows Henry Marsh as he retraces his grandfather's footsteps through Cuba, and  ultimately comes to terms with  his relationship with his father,  Ernie, a famous  and very successful writer   who sadly  developed Alzheimer's  disease. While traveling through Cuba, Henry meets a woman who helps  him come to grips with both his relationship with his father  and  with  his grandfather's legacy.

To Live  Forever was published  29   November 2007 by Bloomsbury Publishing.
