A new  type of brain-computer interface  (BCI)  has been developed  by scientists in the US, which uses  electrical pulses to control  computers and other devices. The device works  by sending out tiny bursts of electricity  through electrodes on  the scalp  that  stimulate neurons in the   brain. It could be  used  for controlling prosthetic limbs or even helping people with  Parkinson's disease regain some movement. Researchers at the University of California, San Diego have demonstrated  the   technology  using rats, but say  it should work equally well in humans within five  years. "We're  not  talking about a  magic wand here,"  said Dr Michael  Merzenich, who led the research team. "This  is something you can put on your head." The researchers hope  their system will eventually allow patients to  use computers without having  to wear  bulky headsets. They are also working on ways to make the BCI  more comfortable  for   users.

In   addition to being able to control computers, this BCI would also be useful  for treating Parkinson's Disease. This is because the disease causes the loss of  dopamine  receptors in  the brain, which leads to tremors and  rigidity.  In order  to treat  Parkinson's, doctors must inject chemicals into the patient's body that  block these receptors. However, if the drug is administered too early, it may cause side  effects such as nausea, vomiting,  and  diarrhea. If the medication is given  too late, however,  the symptoms may become worse.

If the BCI were to be implanted under the skin, it  would be much easier to administer the drugs. Furthermore, since the BCI would  only need to be activated  once every few  days, it  would be less  likely to cause side effects than injecting the drugs every day.

However, there are still many questions surrounding this BCI.  For example, how long does the stimulation last? How do the signals  travel between the brain and the  electrode caps? What happens when  the signal reaches the   cap? And what happens if the signal  is interrupted? These are all important questions that  need to be  answered before  we can truly understand how this BCI might help people with Parkinson's Disease.

UK officials had been  hoping  for a breakthrough by the end of the week which would permit them  to send back suspects. As it turned out, they got  none. Theresa May, the Home  Secretary, said today  that Britain would not be sending  anyone back "for these  people are UK residents". She defended the immigration system against charges that it  discriminates against those with suspected ties to terrorism  and  said: "Those  who  seek to exploit this  system  to  gain  uncontrolled entry to the UK are committing a criminal  offence."

Here's  how the   BBC explained the decision:

A  Home  Office spokeswoman insisted that no British citizen  would be excluded   if  they entered Syria from Turkey, Lebanon  or Tunisia. She  said it was  not appropriate  to return British nationals to their home countries  due  to "the sheer volume of people we have had to deal with  so far". "In relation to those who  make that journey, they have our absolute assurance that  they will not be sent back   this is the  view of the home secretary, this is the view of the government and this is the view of the intelligence agencies," she told BBC Breakfast.  The  spokeswoman said  that the Home  Office only began to  make  efforts to send back refugees in March 2015, adding that the government had not been  able to convince  all EU countries to join them in this  action. In the UK,  this could be  taken  up in Parliament or by  the new Home Secretary, Amber Rudd, she said.

The  earnings of Foreign   Secretary  William Hague have been revealed in the register  of MPs' interests.

The list shows he   received 140,000 for writing a book about his time as leader of the  Conservative Party.

He also  got 22,916  for after-dinner speeches and 15,000 for two articles for the Daily Telegraph.

Italian drinks group Illva Saronno is  to buy a majority stake in a Chinese wine producer as it looks to tap into the country's   growing appetite for the tipple.

The   maker of the  popular Disaronno liqueur said it  would pay 20m  ($22.6m;  14.6m) for a  51% stake in Great Wall.

The deal comes as China's wine market is forecast to grow by a fifth this year.

Illva said the  move would help  it become a "leading player" in the Chinese market.

The company, which also owns the Martini vermouth brand, said it  would  invest a further 10m in Great Wall over the next three years.

"This is a  strategic investment for Illva  in one   of the most interesting and fastest-growing markets   in the world," said chief executive Paolo Marchesini.

"It  will enable  us to become a leading player in the premium segment of  the  Chinese wine market."

Great Wall, which is based  in Shandong province  in  eastern China,  produces  about 10m bottles  of wine a year.

Its wines are currently sold in more  than 20 countries,  including the US,  Canada, Australia and Japan.

The deal  is expected  to be  completed by the end of  the year.

The Oscar-nominated actor  Michael J Fox   is  backing plans for a new theatre in the town where he grew  up.

The Back to the   Future star has donated money to the fundraising campaign for the proposed Michael J Fox Theatre in Burnaby, British Columbia.

The 1,200-seat venue would stage  everything from  musicals to  comedy shows.

Fox, who was born in  Edmonton,  Alberta, but moved to Burnaby as a child, said   the theatre would  be a "great asset" to the community.

"I have very fond memories of growing up in Burnaby and attending shows at the old  Burnaby Senior  Secondary School auditorium," he said in  a statement.

"A new  theatre  would be a great  asset for the entire community."

The project  is expected to cost C$60m (34m)  and construction could begin as early  as next  year.

The future of  ballet in the  UK is  under threat,  a group of dancers has warned.

The dancers,   who are all members of the Royal Ballet, say  the art form is in decline and that there are  not enough opportunities  for young dancers to progress.

In a  letter to the Times newspaper, they  say the UK is   "losing its  position as a world  leader in ballet".

The dancers  say the government should do more to  support ballet  and invest in the  art form.

The letter has been  signed by 26  dancers, including former Royal Ballet principal   dancer Tamara Rojo and  current first soloist Francesca Hayward.

The dancers say ballet is  "facing an existential crisis" and that the art form is "in decline".

They say there are not  enough opportunities  for young  dancers to progress and that the government should do more to support ballet.

The letter has been sent to the Department for  Digital, Culture, Media and Sport,  as well as  the Arts Council England.

Car production  at Ford's European operations has fallen  by almost a quarter this year, but  the US giant  says it  is still on track to make  a profit.

Ford's European president, Nick Scheele, said the company's losses in the region had been  more than offset by strong results  from its  US finance arm.

"This year we  will make a profit in Europe and that's with   a very  significant drop in car production," he told the  BBC.

"Last year we  lost $254m  (130m) in Europe. This  year we  will make a profit. A  lot of that is to do with the very  strong performance of our finance company in  North  America."

Ford's US finance business has been helped by  low interest rates,  which  have  allowed it to  offer cheap loans  to buyers.

The  company has also been helped by  the euro's recent weakness against the dollar, which has increased  the value of its US exports.

Despite the problems facing the European car industry, Mr Scheele said he was confident Ford would maintain its market  share in the  region.

"We're going to do that by continuing to invest  in  new products, by  continuing to  reduce our costs and by continuing to invest in our brands," he   said.

"We think we've got  the right  strategy  in place and  we're beginning to see the results of that."

Former Prime  Minister Tony Blair  has reportedly initiated a plan to win  back Jewish support  for the Labour Party. This agenda  has surfaced at   a time when  the party has been experiencing a considerable decline in popularity among Jewish voters, largely due  to accusations  of institutional anti-Semitism within the  party.

Mr. Blair,  who led  the Labour Party from 1994 to 2007, has started his   campaign by holding   private meetings with  several Jewish leaders.  It is understood these meetings  are aimed at rebuilding trust  between  the Jewish community  and   the Labour  Party. His campaign also includes hosting a  series  of talks dedicated to tackling anti-Semitism and promoting Jewish culture,  contributions, and community.

This move by Blair comes in response  to a recent poll from the Jewish Chronicle that showed 86% of Jewish voters would not consider voting for Labour in future elections. This leaves Labour with only 14% of potential  Jewish votes - a figure that has alarmed party officials  and triggered Blair's  action plan.

Mr.  Blair's spokesperson confirmed that the  former prime minister believes the issues  affecting the relationship between Labour and the    Jewish  community "must be confronted  head on".

"The Labour party has always stood  for equality, justice, and  respect for all communities," said  the spokesperson. "Mr. Blair is well-aware of the challenges ahead but  believes  dialogue  and  open discussions are  key to resolving these problems."

Commenting on the issue, a Jewish leader who wished to remain anonymous, said: "We need proof that the Labour Party  values the Jewish community and that  it is taking  concrete steps to fight  anti-Semitism. Words mean nothing without action."

In  his   attempt to court  Jewish voters, Blair has also planned visits to synagogues and Jewish faith schools, and aims to engage with   Jewish community groups  throughout the  country. His efforts mark a significant   strategic  shift for the Labour Party that is seeking to reinvent and restore its image  in various communities.

However, the success of Blair's initiative  remains to be  seen, especially  considering Labour's recent history.  It will indeed be a challenge for the  former prime minister and the Labour Party to regain the  trust of Jewish voters still strongly dismayed by the party's perceived missteps.

Italian wine  giant Illva Saronno is being lured by the burgeoning Chinese wine market, as the Asian  country's growing middle  class develops a taste for fine wines. 

Illva Saronno, known for producing Disaronno and   Tia Maria,  is considering expanding  its  operations into China, a move that could potentially  boost its global sales and brand recognition. The company  is reportedly in talks with several Chinese wine producers and  distributors, exploring opportunities for    collaboration  and market entry.

China's wine market has  been growing rapidly over the past decade, driven by a rising middle class with increasing disposable income and a growing appreciation for Western  lifestyle and  products. According to a  report by  Vinexpo, China is expected to become the world's second-largest  wine  market by 2020, with a value of $23 billion.

Illva's interest  in China comes   as no surprise,  given the potential for growth.  The company, which  has a strong  presence in Europe and North America, has been  looking to expand its global footprint. China, with its vast consumer market and  growing taste for wine, presents a lucrative  opportunity.

However,  entering the  Chinese market  is not  without challenges. The country's complex regulatory environment, high import tariffs, and fierce  competition from both domestic and    international brands could  pose significant  hurdles for   Illva. Moreover, Chinese consumers'  wine preferences are still evolving, and it remains to be seen whether they will develop a  taste for Illva's offerings.

Despite these challenges, Illva seems undeterred.  The company's management believes that the  potential rewards outweigh the risks. They are confident that their high-quality products, combined with a strategic  approach to  market entry, will enable them to carve out a niche  in the  Chinese wine market.

Illva's move towards China is reflective of   a broader trend in the global  wine industry. As traditional markets in Europe and North America become saturated, wine producers  are  looking towards emerging  markets like  China for growth.  If successful, Illva's foray  into China could pave the way for  other Western wine producers to follow  suit.

The company has not yet released a timeline for its  potential  expansion  into China.  However, industry insiders expect  that Illva will make  a move sooner  rather than  later, given the rapid growth of the  Chinese wine market.

The gadget market is expected to witness a surge in growth in  2005, driven by a  rise in  demand  for mobile devices, gaming consoles, and  new technologies such as wireless  networking, according to market analysts.

They predict that  the gadget  industry could be the primary  beneficiary of a tentative economic recovery, as consumers spend more on  consumer  electronics  and digital devices. According to the  research, smartphone sales are expected to be particularly robust, with their integration  of new  features such as  music and video playing capabilities encouraging consumers to  upgrade their existing mobile devices.

Gaming    consoles are another area set to  experience strong growth this year,  with major releases from Sony and Microsoft anticipated. Both PlayStation 5 and Xbox  Series  X  are expected to boost  game console sales   significantly.

The growth is not only expected in developed  markets like  North America and Europe but also in emerging markets. Technological advancements  in areas like  wireless networking and the growth of the internet are driving demand  for  gadgets.   Devices like WiFi-enabled laptops, smart home  devices, digital  cameras, and  MP3  players are all predicted to  see   increased demand.

Despite the promising outlook, analysts caution that the industry could face challenges. These could include increased competition leading to a price war,  a slower-than-expected rollout of new technology,  or a sudden economic downturn.

They also express concerns for the potential for barriers to international trade due to geopolitical  tensions that can  disrupt  global supply chains. This underscores  the importance  of effective  risk management strategies in the  industry. 

Nevertheless, 2005 appears to be shaping  up to be a growth year for gadget makers.  Those companies that  are able to market their products effectively and stay ahead of technological advancements stand to benefit  the most. 

A notable aspect  of this predicted  growth is that it is not dependent on one kind of product or sector within the gadget industry.  From mobile phones and gaming consoles  to digital  cameras, it seems all gadget  markets have their part in this predicted surge.

This broad-based growth indicates  both the strength of consumer demand for digital  devices and the opportunities  for manufacturers  who  can  deliver innovative and appealing  products.  

In conclusion,  2005 seems set for booming  gadget sales, indicating a positive market trend  for tech and electronics manufacturers. But as  always, the challenges associated with  such growth should not be overlooked. Thus, it  will be interesting  to see how different companies  leverage  this favourable forecast.

Former Foreign Secretary, William Hague, who served under David Cameron from 2010 to 2014, has disclosed earnings  in excess of six figures from an array  of overseas speeches  and consultancy work.

Hague's earnings  from these sources,  separate from  his parliamentary  salary, were shown in the latest  Register of Members' Financial Interests. The register,  updated every  few weeks, helps to maintain  transparency by outlining the financial relationships and interests of parliamentary members.

Of these earnings, research suggests  that a significant proportion was earned from  lucrative speaker slots at  international conferences and functions.  According  to the register,  his  largest single payment of  40,000 came for two speeches delivered during a trip to the United States.

The former Conservative   Party leader also drew a large income from  a variety  of consultancy roles with  multinational  corporations. His advisory role at Teneo  Intelligence, an advisory firm that helps businesses navigate political risks,  and Intercontinental Hotels Group  alone brought in 300,000 annually.

On  top of this,  Hague, who led the Conservative Party  from 1997  to 2001, served on the boards of several non-UK companies, further adding to his income.

The Register of Members Interests  does not include salaries  for  MPs, which are publicly  funded  and set  at 81,932.  It is intended to provide a record of any work carried   out by MPs alongside their duties in  Parliament and show where potential  conflicts of interests may exist. 

This revelation may ignite debate over whether former    ministers should  be allowed  to earn money from private companies and other  non-parliamentary work.  Critics  argue that the second job might distract them from their primary duties, while others believe it may help broaden their perspective  and expertise.

Hague's office  declined to comment on the details of his  earnings. He has  previously  defended taking on additional work, describing it as an opportunity  to gather  wider experience, which  he believed  enhances  the quality of his contribution as an  MP.

Italy's   national football team  is gearing up to  unsettle  England in their upcoming  match, as they aim to exploit any weaknesses in the English side. The Italians are  known  for  their  tactical prowess  and are expected to bring a high level of  intensity  to the game.

The Azzurri, as    the Italian team is  fondly  known, have been in  impressive form recently, with a string of victories under their belt. They are hoping to continue this  winning streak against England, a team they have had a long-standing rivalry with.

Italy's coach,  Roberto Mancini, has been working on  a  strategy to disrupt  England's  rhythm  and exploit any gaps in their defence. "We  have studied England's game closely. They are a strong team, but  like any team, they have their weaknesses.   Our aim is to  exploit those," Mancini said in a pre-match  press conference.

The  Italian team is expected to rely heavily on their experienced players, including veteran defender  Giorgio Chiellini and  midfield maestro Marco  Verratti.  Their experience and tactical understanding of the game will be crucial in unsettling the English  side.

England, on the other  hand, have a young and  dynamic team, led by captain Harry Kane. They  have shown great promise in recent matches, but the  Italian  side is confident of causing an upset.

"We respect England, but we are not afraid of them.  We have the players and  the strategy to rattle them," Mancini added.

The match is expected to  be a thrilling encounter, with  both teams  having a lot to   prove. Italy's aim  to rattle England will not only test the English side's  resilience but also make for an exciting  spectacle  for football  fans around the world.

The stakes are high, and the  tension is palpable as Italy and England prepare to face off.  Whether Italy's strategy to unsettle  England will pay off remains to be seen, but one thing is  certain - football fans are in for a  treat.

Tim Henman,  the  former British number one tennis player, made  a winning start to his career  as a tennis commentator  on Monday. Henman, who retired from professional tennis in  2007, has joined the BBC's commentary team for the grass-court season, and his debut was met with widespread  praise.

Speaking from the BBC's commentary box at Queen's Club,  Henman said, "I'm  thrilled  to  be back in  the world  of tennis, and I'm excited to share my  insights and expertise with the BBC's viewers. I've always been passionate about the sport, and I'm looking forward to bringing that passion to my commentary."

Henman's  first assignment was to cover the opening day  of the Fever-Tree Championships at Queen's Club, where he provided commentary on a series of matches, including the highly anticipated clash between defending champion Feliciano Lopez and rising star Stefanos Tsitsipas.

Chinese  milk bosses have been detained by police,  according to a  BBC  report.  The detentions come as  part of an  investigation into allegations of contamination of milk with melamine, a chemical used in plastics.

The report states that four executives from the Sanlu Group, China's largest milk producer, were taken into custody on Thursday. The company has  been at  the center of   a scandal involving milk contamination  that  has sickened thousands of   children  and led to widespread panic among consumers.

The Sanlu Group has been accused of  knowingly selling contaminated milk powder, which was laced with melamine  to make it appear to have   a  higher protein content. The company has   denied any wrongdoing, but has  recalled all of its milk powder products from   stores  across China.

The  contamination scandal has sparked widespread outrage and calls for greater regulation of  the food  industry. Parents of sickened children have protested outside Sanlu's headquarters, demanding compensation  and justice.

The Chinese  government has  also  come under pressure  to take action, with critics  accusing it of being too  slow to respond to the crisis. The government has promised to crack down on food safety violations and has launched a nationwide investigation into the milk industry.

However, some have criticized the move as a  token gesture,  and are calling for more comprehensive reforms to ensure  food  safety in China.

A thrilling adventure story about a group of explorers who embark  on a perilous journey through  uncharted terrain  has won top honors at this year's prestigious Adventure  Awards ceremony.

The book, titled "The Unmapped  Path," took home the coveted Golden Compass award for   Best  Adventure Story, beating out  stiff competition from a field of talented authors and adventurers.

The  story follows a team  of four friends who set  out to explore a  remote and dangerous region  of  the world, pushing themselves to  their  limits as they   face treacherous landscapes, harsh  weather conditions, and other obstacles along the way.

The author, Alexandra Stewart, said she  was thrilled to  receive the award and praised her fellow nominees for their inspiring tales of adventure.

"I  am truly humbled to have  received this honor  among such an impressive group of finalists," Stewart said  in her  acceptance speech. "My hope is that 'The Unmapped Path' will inspire readers  to seek out  new experiences and  challenges, and to never stop exploring."

Stewart,  who has  been an avid adventurer herself for many years, drew on her own experiences traveling through rugged environments  to create the story. She spent months researching and  preparing   before embarking on the expedition that would  become the basis for   her award-winning  book.

The annual  Adventure Awards celebrate the best in adventure writing, filmmaking, and photography, with winners chosen by a panel  of  experts in  each category.  The awards are highly  regarded within  the adventure community  and are seen  as  a benchmark of  excellence in outdoor pursuits.

In addition to the top prize  for Best Adventure  Story, "The Unmapped Path" also  took home awards for Best Photography and Best Film, making it a clean sweep for the book in the three most prestigious  categories.

Other notable winners at this  year's  Adventure Awards included a documentary  about climbing Mount Everest without oxygen, which won  Best Documentary, and a  collection of photographs showcasing life in some of  the  world's most extreme environments,  which won  Best Portfolio.

In  a surprise move, supermarket  giant Sainsbury's has   announced  that it will be gifting  its employees an extra  day off with pay to encourage them to vote in the upcoming general election.

The company,  which employs over  180,000 people across  the UK, said it wants to ensure that all of  its staff have  the opportunity to exercise their  democratic right and vote on December 12th.

In a statement, a spokesperson  for Sainsbury's said: "We understand that many of  our colleagues may face challenges when it comes to voting,  such as difficulty getting time off work or access  to transportation. Scotland   head coach Gregor Townsend has named   his 31-man squad  for  next month's Six Nations  campaign, with  Glasgow Warriors prop Zander Fagerson and Edinburgh back row Jamie  Ritchie returning after injury layoffs.

Fagerson missed last year's tournament through injury while Ritchie was ruled out by concussion in November.

Glasgow centre Nick Grigg also  makes the cut despite being dropped  for their Champions Cup defeat against Leinster  on Saturday.

The  Scots  open their campaign at home to Italy on Sunday, 2 February (kick off 14:15 GMT).

Townsend said: "We  have selected  a  strong group that we believe can challenge  for  silverware this season."

The judge overseeing the retrial of  John   Warboys for a 2003  murder  has  apologised after comments  made earlier.

Mr Justice Bean said a juror  had been dismissed after being found not to have told the truth  during questioning.

He said he   needed to put on  record "what appears to  have been a misunderstanding" for a transcript of  comments he made.

A  Court of Appeal is hearing  the case  of Woolf, the  youngest  of Warboys'  seven victims.

Mr Justice  Bean had earlier made a reference  to  her "witnesses" -  which is what a juror is technically  called.

'Confusion'

He  said he had not been referring to a  witness who had given evidence in court, but a female friend of 26-year-old Woolf, who was with her at  the  time she died.

"I need  to set  the record straight: there is confusion here, in part because the reference  I  made during an in-court-whisper, about the 'witness', may have been  misunderstood,  and in part because I made a reference to her without going into detail and, in retrospect, I  should have."

Mr Justice Bean told jurors he was  sorry if his words had caused any  confusion.

"I wanted to be very clear about this so I   am making  the point now and hope that it will clear the  air," he   said.

'Disgusted'

Woolf died in 2003 when she was  run  over by Warboys   at the foot of his drive in Gateshead.

A jury  had earlier failed to convict Warboys over her death  and a retrial was ordered.

The 61-year-old is also accused  of murdering two other women -  Lindsay Owen-Jones, 22, from West London, and Ann McDonnal, another  22-year-old whose body has never  been  found.

He has already  been jailed for  seven years for a string  of sexual assaults  and will be sentenced after  the murder case is concluded.

But for now the hearing has become a police investigation.

Budget supercar

>  The  Budget Aston Martin has taken on the might of  Porsche, as the 1959  Aston Martin  DB4GT continues its fight for survival at a Bonhams sale in Marbella, Spain. The  DB4GT is one of  only 75 made, and was once  part of  Aston Martin chairman David Brown's private collection.
>
> The ultra-rare Aston   will be accompanied by another classic DB4GT, at Bonhams' Marbella auction on Sunday.  Both  cars  have less than 600 miles and  were purchased by British businessman David Duckham when the original owner decided to sell them  during the late 1980s.  It's understood that the cars were bought specifically for the  current owner who  has spent the best   part of 25 years restoring them to their original glory.
>
> But  the cars are expected to go  for under  their original   price.  The  DB4GT, which is part of  the original owner's family collection and   is  likely to have been one of the last cars built,  is estimated to  fetch in the region of 2.3m to  2.7m (US$3m to  US$3.47m),  while the other car, a factory competition car believed to have been prepared in the 1960s by Aston  Martin's own competition department, is estimated to make between 1m (US$1.45m) and 1.3m.
>
>
>
> Aside from the DB4  GTs, a 1962   Fiat  Dino  Spyder is expected  to make between 2m and 3m (US$2.8m and US$3.54m), while  a 1955 Mercedes-Benz 300 S Cabriolet A has a pre-sale estimate of  between 1m (US$1.4m) and 1.5m.

Two US men have been found guilty  in   separate cases for running  websites that allowed users to illegally download music and  films, prosecutors say.

Jury members took less than two  hours to convict 28-year-old Eric McGowan on charges  including  conspiracy  to commit  copyright infringement.

He ran the site TVShack.net which offered links to  illegal copies of  movies  and television shows.

In another case, a jury also found 30-year-old Jason Goldman  guilty of similar offences. He operated the website MovieTiger.com.

Both defendants face up to five years  in prison when they are  sentenced later this year.

The verdicts were announced by the  US Department of Justice (DoJ) after  both trials concluded at  federal courts in New York City.

Mr McGowan was accused   of operating TVShack.net between January 2005  and March 2010. It had more than one million   registered users who could access content via BitTorrent file  sharing software.

Prosecutors  said he earned $47,000 (30,000) through advertising revenue during his time as administrator of the  site.

They added that  Mr McGowan's actions caused  losses of about $6m to film  studios   and other rights holders.

Meanwhile,  Mr  Goldman    was charged with running MovieTiger.com -  a site offering  links to unauthorised versions of  Hollywood blockbusters such as Avatar and Transformers.

It was estimated that the site generated  more than  $90,000 in ad revenues over its lifetime.

Microsoft has  announced that it will be offering  a swap program to users who  have purchased pirated copies of Windows XP. The program, which is available until  June 30th, allows eligible  customers  to exchange their   unlicensed copy of Windows XP for a legitimate one at no  additional cost.

To qualify for  the program, users must provide proof of purchase  of  the pirated version of Windows XP and meet certain eligibility requirements. Those  who are  accepted into the  program will receive a new license  key  for a  legal copy of Windows XP, as well as access to any necessary updates  and support.

Microsoft's decision to launch  this program comes in response  to concerns about  the widespread use of pirated software, which  can lead to security  vulnerabilities and other issues. By providing  an easy way for users to switch to   a legitimate version of  the operating system, Microsoft hopes to help protect  both its own business  interests and the broader technology  community.

A UK-based  property company is facing legal  action   in Venezuela over its ownership of thousands of  acres of  land, following allegations that it has failed to  pay taxes and violated local laws.

The dispute centres on a 100,000 hectare estate owned by the  British firm,  which was  acquired from the government in  the  early 2000s as part of a joint venture with a local partner. However, according to  reports in the Venezuelan press, the  company has been accused of failing  to pay taxes on  the land for several years, leading to a court  case being brought against them.

In addition to tax issues, there  are also claims that the company has  breached environmental regulations and failed   to provide adequate  compensation to indigenous communities living near the estate.  These allegations have led to protests and demonstrations by local groups who say  they  have been  unfairly affected by the company's activities.

The UK government has  been contacted by  both sides  in  the dispute,  with representatives  from the property  company  denying any wrongdoing and insisting that they are working closely with the Venezuelan authorities to resolve the issue. The Foreign  Office has said  that it is  monitoring the situation  closely and providing support to  British nationals  involved in the case.

Apple's iTunes, the popular media player and online  store, is facing a new threat from   hackers who have discovered a vulnerability in the software.  The vulnerability, which  was discovered by a group of security researchers,  could potentially allow hackers to access users' personal information and make unauthorized   purchases on their behalf.

The vulnerability, which has  been assigned a severity  rating of "high,"  affects all versions of iTunes,  including the latest version, 12.5.1. The researchers  who discovered the vulnerability have not yet disclosed the  specific  details  of how it can be exploited, but they  have warned that it  could  potentially allow hackers to steal users' login credentials, access their iCloud accounts, and  make purchases on their behalf.

Apple has not yet  released a   patch to  fix the vulnerability, but the company has said that  it is working on a  fix and will release it as soon  as possible. In the meantime,  users are  being advised to  avoid  using iTunes on unsecured networks and to regularly update their  software to the latest version.

The discovery  of the vulnerability  comes at a time when Apple is facing increased scrutiny over its security  practices. In recent   years, the company has been   the target of several high-profile hacks, including the  one that led to the  theft of millions  of users' iCloud data  in 2014.

Apple has  since implemented a number of security  measures  to  improve the security of its products and services,  but the latest vulnerability in iTunes highlights the ongoing challenges of keeping software secure in the face of  increasingly sophisticated attacks.

SEOUL, SOUTH KOREA (REUTERS)  -- South  Korean  police seized   credit  cards belonging to hundreds of  thousands  of consumers and  arrested a key  executive on Thursday after a popular  payment company failed, wiping out  stock  market values and leaving  clients  scrambling   for cash.
South Korea's biggest credit card group failed to  pay banks  as promised on Thursday and on Friday told a court-appointed  investigator that investors had lost about 2 trillion won, or 1.64 billion dollars, in total.
Police said  they had  seized  at least 500,000 cards from South Korea's second-biggest payer by credit sales, Hansung Card.  But they are expecting to uncover an even greater  number of cards, possibly millions,  since they estimate 90 percent of Hansung customers held cards  with other  companies.
The  company had been   selling prepaid cards for  cash  since mid-October, with which customers could purchase  goods online or at stores.
Officials say Hansung customers  have become panicked after the government allowed banks to hold back funds from Hansung-affiliated   stores, and have started lining up  at card issuers' offices to withdraw cash.
Hansung told the court   it has  about 20 million dollars  in cash in its accounts and another 30  million dollars of pledged assets, but  was unable  to access the latter given the current financial uncertainties.
About 1 trillion  won of Hansung's debt is owed to banks, and it has a total  liability of approximately  4.5 trillion won.  It has so far been unable  to pay the interest on credit card bills, causing some of its partner banks  to  refuse customers cash.
Police say the company's shares, which  have  been suspended  since Oct 12, could be wiped  out.
A Hansung employee said  his company had not told  customers how many cards had been  lost and so they  were coming in to get theirs returned before any more damage was done. "
But he  did not know how many cards have been lost due  to Hansung's failure  and what  would happen to the cards.
Hansung said the company had tried  to inform customers about what it was doing to help them retrieve their cards but  many had not picked up the  cards to replace lost ones.
"The majority  of the customers  have been receiving electronic emails regarding  the measures to  get their new cards, but it has been   difficult to confirm whether or not they  had received  the messages because several days have  gone

England coach  Eddie Jones has named  Liam Williams at full-back for Saturday's Six Nations match against Wales at Twickenham.

Williams, who plays his  club rugby  for Scarlets, has been in sparkling form for Wales this season and has  been rewarded with  his first England start.

Jones has also handed a first cap to Bath prop Charlie Ewels, who comes into  the starting line-up in place of the injured   Alex Corbisiero.

Meanwhile, Harlequins winger Marland Yasaia has been named on  the bench, with Jack Nowell dropping  out of the matchday squad.

England  will be  hoping to   build on their  opening day victory over Italy,  while  Wales are  yet to get their Six  Nations  campaign off the  mark.

Shares in  British spirits company Diageo surged on  Monday after reports emerged that it is considering  making a 6bn bid  for France's Pernod Ricard, which could lead to  job cuts and  affect  sales  of  brands such as Jameson Irish whiskey and Malibu rum.
The  potential acquisition has sparked speculation  about how this would impact  iconic  drinks labels owned by both companies, including Martell cognac and Beefeater gin. If successful, the  deal would create the world's largest   liquor business with  annual revenues exceeding $14 billion.
However, sources close to the matter have stated  that no official  approach has been made  yet, with  discussions at an early stage. The move  comes amidst  growing pressure on  big alcohol  firms  to  cut costs amid shrinking consumer demand due to health concerns and rising  taxes.
Analysts predict significant redundancies  if the two  giants merge forces as there might be duplication within  overlapping brand  portfolios, leading to streamlining efforts  across production sites worldwide._

Meanwhile, French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire expressed concern over losing one  of its top luxury goods exporters to foreign ownership but acknowledged talks  were  still preliminary.__

The rapid pace of technological  advancement has led to growing concern  over   its impact on the environment, with experts warning that gadgets and  electronic waste are becoming major environmental challenges. The increasing demand for  smartphones,  laptops, tablets, and  other devices is contributing  significantly to carbon emissions  and e-waste production. According to recent studies, electronics account for  up  to  70% of toxic  waste in landfills worldwide. This alarming trend highlights the urgent need for sustainable manufacturing  practices   and responsible disposal methods to mitigate the negative effects of  technology  on our planet. Experts believe that consumers can  play an important role by choosing environmentally  friendly products and recycling their  old gadgets responsibly. Governments  also have a crucial part to play in addressing this issue  through policies aimed at  reducing energy  consumption and promoting circular  economy principles. As we continue to rely  heavily on digital technologies,  it  is  essential that we prioritize sustainability and take steps  to minimize the harm caused by these innovations to our fragile ecosystem.

The EU's top  court has ruled that the UK government violated the rights of Romani people by failing to recognise them as an ethnic group in  immigration law. The  Court of Justice of  the European Union (CJEU)  said British  legislation was discriminatory because it  did  not cover   Roma as  a  distinct group. The  ruling comes  after a case   brought by the son of  a Romani  woman  who was denied  citizenship because  her partner was not classified as a member of a "racial  group." The court said the British government's policy  of only recognising people who are members of "racial groups" was discriminatory and breached EU law. The UK government said it disagreed with the ruling  but would study it carefully.

In the House of Fortune, secrets  lie,
Whispers of destiny, floating high.
A tapestry woven with threads of fate,
Where dreams and desires congregate.

Within these walls, a mystical dance,
Where chance and luck  intertwine, enhance.
Fortune's  hand, a fickle guide,
Leading  some to glory,  others to hide.

The House of Fortune, a  realm untamed,
Where destinies are forged,   unnamed.
A roulette wheel spins,   destiny's game,
As souls seek fortune,  fame, and acclaim.

Here,  the  gambler's heart   beats fast,
As hopes and dreams are cast.
Cards are dealt, dice are thrown,
In this house, the unknown is  known.

But beware,  for fortune   can deceive,
A fleeting  mistress, quick to leave.
In the House of Fortune, one must be wise,
For every gain, there's  a sacrifice.

Yet, amidst  the uncertainty and strife,
There's  a glimmer of hope, a chance at life.
For in this  house, where fortunes are won,
There's a possibility  for everyone.

So step inside, take  a chance,
Embrace  the chaos, the circumstance.
For in the House of  Fortune, you  may find,
A destiny that's uniquely designed.

When mighty Marlborough leads his warlike  bands,
The  fate of  kingdoms trembles in his hands.
His veteran troops, with fame  and honour   known,
Have made the  proudest enemy to own
That skill  and  valour  here united reign,
And  Europe owns this hero's glorious reign.

Behold  him  now, in triumphs great and high,
Where victory attends  him in the sky.
Exalted on the wings of fame, he soars,
And spreads his conquering banners on distant shores.
No danger  daunts him, no fatigue retards
The  progress  of his  arms, his brave regards.

Through fields of death, where  loud the cannons roar,
He  fearless leads the charge, and gains the shore.
With boldness, wisdom, and with strength untired,
He drives  opposing hosts, with blood admired.
No industry prevails, nor art can save,
Where Marlborough commands, he conquers or he leaves.

To grateful nations, he transmits their laws,
And gladly yields  them from oppression's cause.
The slave,  released, now knows his native  rights,
And tastes the sweets of freedom's fair delights.
The injured  Thames, long groaning  in alarms,
Now sees  the  ravished nymphs restored  to arms.

O thou,  great  Marlborough, whose exalted name
Shines like   a meteor in the lists of fame,
Thy deeds shall fill the sounding trump  of fate,
And thy  own words  shall  best  recite thy state.
Thy monuments,  renowned through future days,
Shall for thy martial worth  transmit thy praise.
Thy country's love, thy prince's just regard,
Shall prove  the blessings of a   great reward.

Long may thy life and glory still endure,
And showers of blessings  on thy head  secure.
May victory and honour still attend
Thy warlike steps, thy sacred person defend.
While  thankful millions sing thy   great success,
And hail  thee, Marlborough, with  joy and happiness.

In step with one another, side by side,
We wander through the  world, our  spirits tied.
Through fields of green  and forests deep,
Our  souls  entwined,   our secrets we keep.

Hand in hand, we face the unknown,
Together we conquer, we're not alone.
Through stormy weather and  darkest night,
Our love shines bright, a guiding light.

With every step, our bond grows strong,
In harmony  we move, where we  belong.
Through laughter and tears, we  share it all,
Our hearts connected,   never  to fall.

Through winding paths and mountains high,
We   journey on, beneath the  open sky.
With every stride, we find our way,
Together  we walk, come what may.

Through  life's twists and turns, we navigate,
Our love unwavering, never to abate.
With every  footfall, we leave a  mark,
Walking together, through light and dark.

In sync  we  move, our rhythm in tune,
Our love a melody, beneath the moon.
Through valleys low and peaks so high,
We  walk together,  you and  I.

Within the realms of memory we find
A space reserved for those who've  passed away.
Their presence still remains, their  spirits bind
Us in their love, forever  and a day.

These sonnets penned, a tribute to their souls,
Capture the essence of their timeless grace.
Their laughter, warmth, and love our hearts console,
As tears  are shed for them in this  embrace.

Gone from  this mortal realm, they still  reside.
Their  spirit lingers, whispering on the breeze.
In dreams they visit,  close by  our  side,
Reminding us  of all the joy  they seize.

Within our thoughts  and hearts forever more,
Their  memory   lives on,  we can't ignore.

Though fickle is the path we  tread,
And serendipity at times  feels lost,
Still as the stars our  course is set,
Entwined in destiny's deliberate hand.

No matter how we strive  and chase,
The universe its  plans will lay,
We may stumble and we may  fall,
But purpose  whispers  through it  all.

For in the tapestry woven deep,
Fate's gentle thread finds  its way,
Guiding us to encounters profound,
Where love and longing are bound.

Across the oceans,  mountains high,
Through the darkest  nights we   sigh,
Destiny awaits with open arms,
An eternal dance of wondrous charms.

In moments unexpected, surreal,
Our lives   connected in a cosmic  reel,
Serendipity's  sweet  smile  unfurls,
Uniting souls, two halves of  a whole.

With every heartbeat, breath we take,
Our destinies align, no choice to  make,
For intertwined are our paths  divine,
Bound together,  by life's grand design.

Sure I'm absolved your Grace of all blame
In sailing hence to Cadiz:
But  as your friend, I beg  you'll  hear me
Just for a  minute.
When this   unlucky fleet was order'd
To sail for the south,
To  join our cousins, men of honour,
That's  when our  troubles began.

Barely out of port we met 'em
In  ev'ry direction
Of all your army,  which I told ye
From the  beginning.
'Twas more than just a pleasure
To welcome Prince George
And all your gallant army,
Which land'd them here,
And though inclined to heaviness
They'd keep us all   from harm.

They'd boast about   the French fleet
Being  chased to the  shore,
And  how they'd captured   cities
Both  seaports  and border towns,
Burnt docks and warehouses
And scatter'dplots of corn.

And  thus they'd keep us cheerful
Until we'd anchor'd   here,
Where we  found five French frigates
Ahead of us, it   seem'd  clear.
With one sail  in the distance,
Which they made  haste to chase,
And we  were   order'd  after  'em
Not to lag behind.

It was  scarce a mile behind us
When we made 'em out
Seven ships of the  line pursuing
Our scouts, it was a  dismal  sight.
With colours flying  we gave 'em chase
As  fast as we were able;
But soon we saw them  scattering
Each ship to save herself.

Then we came up with   their rear ships
Where  gallant action was to be seen
'twas then we learnt they'd scatter'd
And so we  took what prize we could.
Full carp'd  at by  the Dutch
We'd let one fifty-gun ship escape us,
And fear'd she'd give  the game away.

A council held, we soon decided
To chase the fugitives
For fear they'd  reach the  Dutch
And so we steered   due East.
We scarce had reached the station
When the clouds gave  place to the moon,
Which shining bright on the Dutchman
We could see him lurch and list.

At ten  they hail'd us, but no answer
For fear of being  known;
But we could see them plainly
And they could see us  too.
We could see each other's fleet
As plain as moonlight would allow,

Dear Lord,  lead me to heaven,
Lead  me to eternal life;
I do  not wish to go  to hell,
And burn  in eternal fire.

I  know that I   have sinned,
And I  truly repent;
I believe  in You, and  Heaven,
And I want to follow You.

Please, Lord, forgive me;
Lead me  from the evil one's  trap.
Fill my  heart  with joy and peace,
And take away my sadness  and despair.

I wish to follow You forever,
And live in the house of the Lord;
Lead me to heaven, and I will
Praise Your holy name. Amen.

Weather Permitting
by Philip   Booth

If the weather permits, we'll take the children
To the sands,  and watch  the mighty  surges
Of the Pacific pounding at  his feet,
And fetching down deep  loads of boulders
From the headlands. If the  weather permits.

If the weather permits,  we'll  show the children
The grey bulk   of  Alcatraz,  fortress
And prison,  where   the  hardest of criminals
Were contained,  although it never stopped them
From  attempting to  escape. If the weather permits.

If the  weather permits, we'll take the ferry
Back to the wharf, and eat crab salads
And look at the sea-gulls, while at anchor
The ferry lingers, and the sun  sinks slowly
Behind  the Golden Gate. If the weather permits.

Author's  Note: As the weather in San Francisco  can be cooler even in summer, visitors may need to  wear warmer clothes, and take the cable-car to  Chinatown, and browse the shops, and eat in an excellent Chinese restaurant, the City Hue.

To our country, and to  all of us.

This poem is all about images that have   different  meanings for different people. For those who have a  visual identity, it can be hard to express themselves with  words, but by seeing   something  once or twice, people create connections. For  those with a conceptual identity, it's much harder to express why an image  is interesting  or meaningful. What images evoke for an  individual? "What is  the  image?" may be  the first question that comes to mind.  For someone  else,  looking "that" way or seeing   "that" image  and  knowing they are looking at it "that way" may  cause  thoughts of that image to pop up. For another, being familiar with  an image  can  bring meaning to the image. Some people find meaning from the  way an image looks, and others see it as a representation of  themselves. For the person looking at  a piece of  art for  the first time, it could be all about that image.A person's identity may have roots in  their past with images. A new artist  may be attracted by the same images or ideas that  have already captivated others. Even when a  person is  trying to understand how  concepts of  identity tie into images they have encountered, it may take time to find  the answer. A new  viewer may see "the image," but it does not necessarily mean the image  makes   him or her a different person. "What is this piece doing to you and how is this looking into your mind?" can be a very  common   and helpful question to  ask when trying to  understand images.For many of us, images can be  powerful sources of ideas about ourselves. We can use  images as guides, as a vehicle for    communication, or as a place  to seek new things. An image is usually taken in one moment;  it can be a very powerful source of inspiration  for an   individual, but  it has   several limitations. For most of us, images are often  limited to specific   places, times,  or forms of  life. The fact that images are more often  than not limited to one place  or one time can cause a person to   feel as  though  the image has  no meaning.  Images often look and feel very "limited"but  they are not. We see in our dreams the same kind of images, but in  the dream  we know we are  dreaming because   we know what an image is and we are  not fooled because we  see a world  that is quite different from our own. A  Grammarians Funeral

Shortly after  the revival of learning,

A great  grammarian died;

They huddled round his bier  to  burn him,

And all  the while he cried:

"Oh, leave me to my books and learning,

And do not touch my dust;

For if you  do, you'll only find

A  pedant  and a crust."

The moral of this story is:

Don't be a  pedant  or you'll end  up like this grammarian!

The Argument

Satan, now repenting of his rebellion, and  fearing  the torments that he is  to undergo, resolves to return to heaven, and to submit  to God. His design  is discovered by Uriel,  who, by God's command, drives  him from heaven. Satan, after wandering about in the dark for  some time, finds Beelzebub,  and tells him of his  design, which he advises him to abandon. They then consult about what  is to be done, and,  after some debate,   resolve to build a palace in   hell, which they accordingly do.

They debate  about what  is to be done   and resolve to build a palace in   hell.

In  the heart of  the forest,  where the sunlight gleams,
Stands an ancient  oak, whispering tales of dreams.
Beside it,  a broom,  humble and small,
Together they stand, the tallest of all.

The  oak, with its branches, reaching   for the sky,
A  testament of time,  under the sun's watchful eye.
Its roots, deep and strong,  gripping the  earth,
A symbol  of endurance,  of unyielding worth.

The broom,  with its blossoms, a golden  delight,
A beacon of hope, in the  darkest night.
Its  stems, thin and flexible, bending with  the  breeze,
A testament  of resilience, of a strength that never ceases.

The  oak and   the broom, an unlikely  pair,
One grand and  majestic, the other  simple and fair.
Yet,  together they  stand, in the forest's embrace,
A testament of harmony, in this vast, wild space.

The oak shares its wisdom, of ages gone  by,
Of seasons that change, under  the endless sky.
The broom offers comfort, with its gentle sway,
A reminder that   beauty, in simplicity lay.

In the heart of the forest, where  the moonlight gleams,
The oak and  the broom, share their silent dreams.
A tale of  companionship, of love that's untold,
In the dance of the oak and the broom, a story unfolds.

So, listen to the whispers, of   the wind in the trees,
Of the oak and the broom, and  their silent  pleas.
For  in their tale,  a lesson is found,
Of strength in unity, of love that's profound.

In   the hallowed halls  of  history, where shadows whisper tales,
Lies the ancient  wisdom, in parchment   and in brails.
A  remedy for every wound, a balm for every pain,
A  potion brewed from time  itself, to make the weary sane.

The  olden herbs, the  sacred roots, the crystals kissed by  moon,
The  chants that echo through the night, the  sun at high noon.
The secrets whispered by the wind,  the  stories told by fire,
The healing touch of Mother Earth, fulfilling every desire.

The  dance of leaves in autumn's breath, the winter's silent song,
The spring's   sweet kiss  on blooming buds, the summer days so long.
The  rhythm of the  universe, the pulse of life so grand,
Is the medicine we  seek, in the palm of  our hand.

The wisdom  of  the ancients,  the knowledge of the old,
Is the cure  for modern  ailments, more precious than gold.
The whispers of  the forest, the murmurs of  the sea,
Are the time-tested remedies, setting our  spirits free.

The  laughter of a child, the comfort of a  friend,
The love that knows no boundaries, the peace that knows no end.
The  joy  in simple moments, the  strength in standing tall,
Is  the medicine of time, the greatest cure of all.

So,   listen to the silence, hear the universe's   rhyme,
Embrace the ancient wisdom, the time-tested divine.
For in the dance of life and death, in every rise and fall,
The medicine of time,  is the healer of us all.

In the grand tapestry  of  time, woven by  unseen hands,
Each thread a  life, each  color a choice, each pattern a plan.
We are  but stitches in the cosmic  dance,
Bound  by the rhythm of circumstance.

We are the dreamers, the  seekers, the   lost,
In the vast ocean  of existence, tempest-tossed.
Yet, within  us, a  compass,   a  guiding star,
A whispering wind that calls from afar.

Through the labyrinth of life, we  wander and roam,
Each path we tread,  a step towards home.
In the silence of the night, in  the  roar  of the day,
In every heartbeat, destiny  has its say.

In the mirror of the soul, in the  heart's  deep well,
In the  silent stories that  our eyes tell,
In the echoes of laughter,  in the tears we cry,
In the tapestry of time, our destiny lies.

We are the poets,  the  painters, the song,
We are the right in  a world gone wrong.
In the dance of  the cosmos,  in the rhythm of the sea,
In every breath, we are our destiny.

In the silence between heartbeats,  in the pause  between words,
In the hush  of the dawn, in  the song of  the birds,
In the spaces  between stars, in the depth of the night,
In the dance of destiny,  we find our light.

So, let us dance to  the rhythm, let us play  our part,
With courage  in our  minds and love in our heart.
For in the grand   tapestry of time, woven so fine,
Each thread, each color, each pattern is divine.

Black cloth drape the  sky,
Muffled drums beat in rhyme,
A procession marches  by,
  paying respects to time.

The casket,  sleek and dark,
Reflects the  sorrow  felt,
White roses on  its surface,
a symbol of love unrelent.

Faces stand with tears,
recalling memories past,
funny moments shared,
and laughter that will last.

In this final farewell,
We bid adieu,
To one  who  lived full,
And left  us  too soon, yet true.
Though gone from sight,
Your legacy lives  strong,
May it guide   those present,
As their future unfolds long.

My  brother, oh how    I adore,
A constant friend,  a love so pure,
With a heart of  gold and  a  smile so bright,
He lights up  my  life, day and night.

His  laughter is music to  my ears,
His  hugs, a  comforting embrace,
He brings joy to all our fears,
And chases away the tears we race.

He's my partner in every crime,
My accomplice in every venture,
Together we roam the land,
And share   each  other's deepest  pleasure.

His kindness knows  no  bounds,
His generosity, a never-ending spring,
He gives without expecting anything,
And always puts others  first, no need to sing.

My brother, oh how  I'm blessed,
To have you in my life, I'm  so grateful,
You're more  than just a sibling,
You're  my friend, my confidant, my soul's kin.

So  here's to you, my sweet  brother,
A shining star in every weather,
I'm lucky to call you my own,
My heart, my everything, my forever home.

In gardens  full of color, life,  and hues,
We find our family, in roses anew.
Their  petals  soft as skin, their scent so sweet,
A symphony of love, can't be beat.

In reds and pinks, they dance with   grace,
Uncle Jack stands out  in his favorite place.
Aunt Lily sways to  rhythm of her name,
Her  beauty  like the rose, forever remains.

With orange tones, Cousin Sarah shines,
Bright lights on summer  evenings divine.
While Dad, the gentle giant, wears a grin,
His pride for us is   always spinning within.

Mom, oh Mom, a vision in pure white,
Guiding   us through life  with all her might.
Nurturing like  the flower she  adores,
Love for us, she never ignore.

The garden grows, with    time it  thrives,
Like our bond that forever survives.
This family of roses  strong and true,
Echoing  love songs, our  hearts renew.

>
>  There were puddles everywhere,
> And they splashed up  against me,
> As if they  wanted to get into my   boots.
>  But  I didn't mind them at all,
> For  I knew that  when I got home,
> I could  take off my wet clothes,
> And put on some dry ones.
>
> The rain fell so hard,
> That it  made a noise like thunder,
>  And the wind blew so strong,
> That it almost knocked  me down.
> But I held onto my umbrella tight,
> And  kept walking  until  I  reached  my destination.
>
> When I finally arrived,
> I was soaked through and through,
> But I felt refreshed  and invigorated,
> Like I  had just taken a  dip  in the ocean.
>
> So next  time you see a city  shower coming your way,
> Don't let it dampen your spirits,
>  Embrace its power and enjoy  the  ride!

When I saw this beautiful woman walk through the  door.
She sat down at  the  end of the bar and ordered a drink.
As  she turned to face me, I noticed  that her eyes were as  blue as  the sky on  a  clear summer day.
Her  hair was long and blonde, and it fell   softly  over her shoulders.
She had a smile  that could light up  any room, and I knew right away that I wanted to get to know her better.
We started talking, and before we knew it, hours  had  passed by. We talked about everything under the   sun, and I found  myself falling  for her more with every word she spoke.
Finally, it was time for us to  go our  separate ways. As she  got  up to leave, she looked back  at  me and said,  Youre not going to   forget about me,  are you? With those words still ringing in  my ears, I watched her walk out  the door. And then I realized something  I didnt  want to forget about her either. So heres hoping that one day  soon fate will bring  us together again

Where sand  meets sea in harmony
And all my  worries fade away to  nothingness

The  sun above, so warm and bright
Bathing me  in its golden light
I close my   eyes and breathe it in
As all my stresses start to spin

The waves they crash upon the  shore
A symphony that could  never  bore
Each one unique, with power  and grace
Washing over me, a calming embrace

Alone, I   am free to be myself
Without judgment or need for   wealth
To live in this moment, pure and true
Is all I ever wanted, just for me and you

So here on this private beach
I will lay down  and rest my weary head
For in  this tranquil  paradise
All  my troubles will  eventually dissolve

Sometimes I  feel you, a gentle breeze   
A  whisper on my cheeks, a  fleeting ease   
As if your  love, a warm embrace   
Wrapped me up in its softness, its grace

As I walk this journey, with you by my side.

In the heart of Beijing,  on a day  in  June,
A tragedy unfolded, a  moment of truth.
On the streets of Tiananmen Square,
A peaceful protest, a call  for fair share.

The people stood up, their voices raised  high,
For democracy and freedom, they would not comply.
The government responded with   force and might,
Crushing the protests, ending  the fight.

The world watched in horror,   as the  tanks rolled  in,
The sound of gunfire, a chilling din.
Hundreds of people, their lives  cut short,
A moment of darkness, a human   cost.

But the memory lives  on, a flame of hope,
For those who  fought, for  those who  spoke.
The people of  China, will  never  forget,
The day of June 4th, when  their voices were met.

And though the  government tries to  suppress,
The truth will always be a source  of stress.
For the people of China,  their fight will continue,
Until they achieve the freedom they desire to obtain.

The rivers that once flowed free and  wild,

The sun blanched blood of the earth is  mild,

So let us  remember the sun blanched blood of the earth,
And cherish each moment, for  life  is  but a breath,
Let us strive to live with purpose and mirth,
And leave behind a  legacy that  will never  wither or die.

The  house  of dust, once grand and tall,
now crumbles to the ground, a sight most gruesome, and  yet,
there's beauty in the decay, it seems,
for nature takes its course, without extremes.

The windows,  once  so clean and bright,
now  coated thick  with grime and dirt,
the memories that linger in the air
indelible, but lost,  forever  spirt.

Yet,  in the shadows, secrets lie,
and ghosts of passions   past still cling,
the echoes  of  their laughter and their cries,
forever trapped  within these ancient walls.

For this house of  dust, it holds the key,
to unlock the door,  you must let  go,
of the  past and all its bitter sway,
and   find the light that shines beyond its sway.

So let the dust  envelop you, my dear,
and let the past  fade to a mere blur,
embrace the change, embrace the new,
and let the house  of  dust become anew.

A love that  will never die.

In the  town of Newbury, there's  a  tale of  old,
Of a snake with two heads,  that once  did roam,
It's said that   this creature, with its double gaze,
Would strike fear into the hearts of all  who  gaze.

Some say it  lived in  the woods, deep in the trees,
Others claim it slithered through  the streets with  ease,
But one  thing was certain,  wherever it went,
Trouble followed close behind,  like a shadow in a tent.

The people of  Newbury tried to stay  far,
Away from the double-headed  snake, they did their best to bar,
But  it  seemed that wherever  they went,
The snake  would find them, and their fears would  be sent.

It's said that one day, the snake was finally slain,
By a brave hunter, with a heart of purest grain,
He tracked it down, and  with a single blow,
He severed both of its heads, and  the creature did know.

And though some  say, the snake still roams to this day,
In the shadows, waiting for its  chance to  play,
I  think of the hunter, and his courage true,
And I know that   the snake, will never  come through.

For when our boss takes time to guide,
And treats us right from morning till night,
