Our hearts are  filled with happiness so sweet.

With kind words that uplift  our soul,
He makes each  day worth waking up  for;
His leadership   inspires us  whole,
To be  better people than  before or more.
So let this   message reach far and wide,
That happy bosses make their team thrive,
Their   guidance leads them through life's strife,
Showing love and care without any disguise.

In  turn, employees will strive to give,
Their best performance  all live  long;
Because they know it brings him delight,
They'll go  above and beyond what was required at night.
Oh how blessed we are   to have such an one,
Who sees potential within everyone,  helping  those who've been  left alone.

Thus may these lines serve  as reminder  true,
Of just how much power lies in you;
As leader, mentor, friend indeed,
You hold key to your worker's success-filled need.
Be  mindful  then of heart and  mind,
Lest anger  boil inside instead.

Instead choose kindness  always tenderly,
Let patience reign supreme daily;
By doing thus shall both employee and employer find,
True fulfillment on path leading  towards destiny designed.

Duck Dumplings Recipe:

Ingredients:
- 1  cup cooked duck meat, shredded
- 1 cup  all-purpose  flour
- 1/4 cup water
- 1/4 cup green onions, finely chopped
- 2   cloves garlic, minced
-  1 tablespoon  soy   sauce
- 1 tablespoon sesame oil
- 1/2 teaspoon salt
-  1/4 teaspoon black pepper
- Vegetable oil,  for frying
-   Dipping sauce (optional)

Instructions:

1. In a mixing bowl, combine  the shredded duck  meat, green onions,  garlic, soy sauce, sesame oil, salt,  and black pepper. Mix well to combine all  the flavors.

2.  In a separate bowl, gradually add water  to the  all-purpose flour, stirring until  a  dough forms. Knead the dough  for a few minutes  until  it becomes smooth and elastic.

3.  Roll  out the dough on a lightly floured surface  until  it is about 1/8 inch thick. Use a round cookie cutter or a glass to cut out circles from the  dough.

4.   Place a spoonful of the duck  filling in the center of each  dough circle. Fold the dough in half, sealing the   edges by pressing them  together firmly. You can also crimp the edges  with a fork for a decorative touch.

5. Heat vegetable oil in a frying pan over medium heat.  Carefully place the dumplings  in the hot  oil, making sure not to overcrowd the pan. Fry the dumplings for about  2-3 minutes on each side, or until they  turn golden brown.

6. Remove the dumplings from the pan and place them  on  a paper towel-lined  plate to  drain excess  oil.

7. Serve the duck dumplings  hot with a dipping sauce of your choice, such as soy  sauce  or a spicy chili sauce.

Enjoy your delicious homemade duck dumplings!

Ingredients:
- 1  lb dried split  peas
- 1  large onion,  diced
- 2   carrots, diced
- 2 celery stalks, diced
- 4 cloves of garlic, minced
- 2 tbsp  olive oil
- 1 fennel  bulb, thinly sliced
- 2 cups lobster meat, cooked and chopped
- 1 lemon,  juiced
- Salt and  pepper to taste
-  Fresh parsley, chopped  for garnish

Instructions:
1. Rinse the  split peas thoroughly and drain them.
2. In a large pot, heat the  olive oil over medium   heat.  Add the onion,  carrots, celery, and garlic. Cook until the vegetables are tender, about  5 minutes.
3.  Add  the split peas to the pot and cover with water. Bring the  mixture to a boil and then reduce  the heat to a  simmer. Cook for about 40 minutes or until the peas are  soft and beginning to break  down.
4. While the soup is  simmering,  preheat  the oven  to 400F.  Spread the sliced fennel on a baking sheet and drizzle with olive oil. Roast for about  20 minutes  or until the fennel is tender and lightly caramelized.
5.  In a bowl, combine the chopped lobster meat with the lemon juice, salt, and pepper. Toss to coat the lobster meat  evenly.
6. Once the  split peas are cooked, use a blender or immersion blender  to puree  the soup until smooth.  Alternatively, you can leave some chunks if  you prefer.
7. Season  the soup    with salt and pepper to  taste and simmer  for another 5 minutes to  allow the flavors  to  meld.
8. To serve, ladle the split pea soup into bowls and top with the  roasted  fennel slices and a spoonful of the lobster  salad. Sprinkle with chopped parsley for garnish.
9. Enjoy the split   pea  soup with roasted fennel and lobster salad hot.

Ingredients:
- 4 chicken thighs,  bone-in and skin-on
- Salt and pepper to taste
- 2 tablespoons olive  oil
- 1 onion, thinly sliced
- 3 cloves garlic, minced
- 1 cup chicken  broth
- 1/2  cup apple cider vinegar
- 2 tablespoons honey
- 1 teaspoon dried thyme
-  1 teaspoon  dried rosemary
-  4 cups  mixed greens (such as kale, spinach, or    Swiss chard), chopped

Instructions:
1. Season the chicken thighs  with salt and pepper on both  sides.
2. Heat the olive oil in a  large skillet over  medium-high  heat. Add the chicken thighs, skin-side down,  and cook until browned, about  5 minutes. Flip  the chicken and cook for  an  additional 3 minutes.  Remove the chicken   from the skillet and set  aside.
3. In the same skillet,  add the  sliced onion and minced garlic. Cook   until the onion is  softened, about 5  minutes.
4. Add the chicken broth, apple cider vinegar, honey, dried  thyme, and dried rosemary to the skillet. Stir to combine.
5.  Return the chicken  thighs to the skillet, skin-side up.  Bring the  liquid  to a simmer,  then reduce the heat  to low. Cover the skillet and let the chicken braise for 30 minutes.
6. After 30 minutes, remove the lid and add  the chopped greens to the skillet. Stir to combine  with the braising liquid. Cover the skillet again and  let the chicken and greens cook for an additional 10 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and the  greens  are  wilted.
7. Serve the  vinegar-braised chicken with greens  hot, spooning some of the braising liquid  over the top.  Enjoy!

Szechuan Crispy Orange Beef Recipe:

Ingredients:
- 1 lb  flank steak, thinly   sliced into  strips
- 1/2 cup cornstarch
- 1/4 cup vegetable oil
- 4 garlic cloves, minced
-  1 tbsp  fresh ginger, minced
- 1  cup orange juice
- 1/4 cup soy sauce
-  1/4 cup rice vinegar
-  2 tbsp brown  sugar
- 2   tbsp honey
-   1 tsp sesame oil
- 2 tsp Szechuan  chili flakes (adjust to taste)
- 1/2 tsp  salt
- 1/4  tsp black pepper
- 1/4 cup green   onions, chopped
- 1  tbsp orange zest, for garnish
- Sesame seeds, for garnish
- Steamed rice, for  serving

Instructions:
1. In a large bowl, coat the sliced flank steak in cornstarch. Use your hands to toss and make sure each piece is well coated.
2. Heat vegetable oil  in a large skillet  or wok over medium-high heat. When the oil is hot, carefully   add  the coated beef slices and fry until golden  brown  and crispy. Remove  beef  from the skillet and set aside on  a paper towel-lined plate to  drain excess oil.
3. In the same skillet, reduce  the heat to medium and add  minced garlic  and ginger. Saut for a  minute until fragrant.
4. In a separate bowl, whisk together  orange juice, soy sauce, rice vinegar, brown sugar, honey, sesame  oil, Szechuan chili flakes, salt, and black  pepper until well combined.
5. Pour the sauce into the  skillet with the garlic and  ginger.  Bring to a simmer and  cook  for 2-3 minutes  until the  sauce  thickens slightly.
6. Add  the  crispy beef back to the skillet and toss until it is evenly  coated in the sauce. Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes until the  beef is  heated through.
7. Garnish with green onions, orange  zest, and sesame seeds.
8. Serve the   Szechuan Crispy Orange Beef over steamed rice and  enjoy!

Title: Fish Broth

Ingredients:
-  1  pound  of  fish bones and heads (such  as snapper, cod, or halibut)
-  1 onion, chopped
- 2 carrots, chopped
- 2 celery stalks, chopped
- 2 cloves  of  garlic, minced
-  1   bay leaf
-   1 teaspoon  of whole  black peppercorns
-  1 tablespoon of olive oil
- 8 cups of water
- Salt,  to taste
-   Fresh parsley,  for garnish (optional)

Instructions:

1. Rinse the fish bones  and  heads under cold water to remove any impurities. Pat them dry with paper towels.

2. In a large pot, heat the olive oil   over medium heat.  Add the chopped onion, carrots, celery, and minced garlic. Saut for about 5 minutes, or until the  vegetables are  softened.

3. Add the fish bones  and heads to the pot,  along with the bay leaf and whole black peppercorns. Stir everything together and cook for  another 2 minutes to allow  the  flavors to  meld.

4. Pour  in the water and bring the mixture to a boil. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low and  let the  broth simmer uncovered for about 30 minutes. Skim off any  foam or impurities that rise to the surface.

5. After 30 minutes, remove the pot from the heat and strain the broth through a fine-mesh sieve or  cheesecloth into  a  clean pot  or bowl.  Discard the solids.

6. Taste  the broth and season with salt  to your liking. Remember that  you can  always add more salt later, so start with a small amount  and  adjust  as  needed.

7. If desired, garnish the fish broth with fresh parsley before serving. This adds a pop of color and freshness to   the dish.

8.  Serve the fish broth hot as a comforting and nourishing soup on its own,  or use it as  a base for other seafood dishes like  chowders or stews.

Note: You  can store any leftover fish broth  in an  airtight container in the refrigerator  for  up to  3 days, or freeze it for longer storage.

Ingredients 
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
1 1/2 teaspoons  baking  powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4  teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 cup buttermilk
2 eggs
2 cups cornmeal
2 tablespoons butter
1/4 cup olive  oil
4 medium green tomatoes, sliced
4 ounces smoked  cheddar cheese, grated

Instructions
1. Preheat oven to 200 degrees F (95 degrees C).
2. In  a small bowl, combine flour,  baking powder, salt, and cayenne pepper.  In  a second bowl, whisk together  buttermilk and  eggs. Soak tomato slices  in  buttermilk mixture for 2 to 3 minutes.
3. In a third bowl, mix  cornmeal and   butter. Remove  tomatoes from buttermilk, allowing excess to drip  off. Dredge  in cornmeal mixture, shaking off excess.
4. Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Fry tomatoes until golden brown,  about  2 minutes on   each side. Drain  on paper towels. Keep  warm in preheated oven.
5. Sprinkle cheese on top of each tomato slice. Serve open-faced  on  toast.

Overview:
A hearty bowl  of split pea soup is  the perfect way to warm up on a cold day. We took this classic recipe and added a delicious  twist  with a flavorful roasted  fennel and lobster salad that will wow  your guests. This soup is easy  to make  and perfect for  a winter  meal.

Ingredients:
1   cup dried split peas,  rinsed and picked through
4 cups chicken broth
1 bay leaf
1 teaspoon fresh  thyme leaves
1/2 cup chopped  onion
1 cup diced roasted fennel (see Note)
1 tablespoon olive oil
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/4  teaspoon ground black pepper
1/2 pound lobster meat, chopped
2 tablespoons fresh lemon  juice
1 tablespoon chopped fresh  parsley

Instructions:
1.   In a large saucepan, combine  the split peas,  chicken broth, bay leaf, and  thyme.  Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, then reduce  the heat to  low and simmer, covered, for 30 minutes, or until the peas are tender.
2. Meanwhile, in a medium skillet,  cook the onion  in the olive oil over medium heat for 3  minutes,  or until  tender.  Add the roasted fennel,  salt,  and  pepper,   and cook for 3 minutes more, or until  the fennel  is tender. Remove from the heat.
3. In a large bowl, combine the  cooked onion and fennel with  the lobster  meat,  lemon  juice, and parsley.
4. When the peas  are tender,  discard the bay leaf and puree  the soup in a blender or food processor. Serve the   soup warm, topped with the lobster and fennel salad.

Note: To make roasted fennel, cut 1 large  bulb of fennel into 1/2-inch-thick slices and toss with 1  tablespoon olive oil and 1/8 teaspoon each salt and  pepper. Roast in a 400 degrees F oven for  20   minutes, or until tender and lightly browned.

Ingredients:
1/2 cup   dairy-free semi-sweet chocolate  chips
1/2 cup dairy-free sweetened  condensed milk
1/4 cup amaretto
1/4 cup  dairy-free sour cream
1 teaspoon dairy-free vanilla extract

Instructions:
1. Place chocolate chips  and sweetened  condensed milk in a bowl. Microwave  1 minute. Stir. Microwave an  additional 30 seconds. Stir until smooth.
2. Stir in amaretto,  sour cream, and  vanilla extract.
3. Pour mixture into  a  9"x5" loaf pan. Cover and freeze overnight.
4. Remove from freezer and let sit 5 minutes before serving.

Ingredients:

1  cup chopped onion
2  tablespoons  butter
2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon  salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
1/4 teaspoon garlic powder
1/4 teaspoon dry  mustard
2  cups chicken broth
1  cup half  and  half
4 cups fresh broccoli florets
1 cup shredded cheddar cheese

Instructions:

1. In a large pot,  cook and stir  the onion in the  butter over medium   heat until the onion is tender, about 5 minutes.  Stir in the flour, salt, black pepper, garlic powder, and dry mustard. Cook for  2 minutes to get the flour taste out.
2.   Stir in   the chicken broth and  half and half. Cook over medium-high heat until the mixture boils, stirring frequently. Stir in the broccoli  and reduce the heat to medium. Cover and cook until the broccoli is  tender, about 10 minutes.
3.  Stir in the cheese until  melted. Serve immediately.

Fish Broth 
Ingredients

1 fish carcass (with head), about 1 1/2 pounds (680  g)
2 carrots, peeled and coarsely chopped
1 rib   celery, sliced
1/2 medium onion, peeled  and coarsely  chopped
10 peppercorns
1/3 cup (79 ml) dry white wine
bay  leaf
4 cups (950 ml) water

Instructions

1. In a large stock pot, combine all  ingredients.
2. Bring to  a boil over high  heat, then reduce  to low, and simmer,  uncovered, for 30  minutes.
3. Remove fish carcass  and any bones.
4. Strain broth through a fine mesh strainer into a large bowl.
5. Use immediately, or  let cool completely before refrigerating or freezing.

Note:   This recipe can be easily doubled if you have a large stock pot.  Simply double all  the ingredients  and   cook according to the instructions. Fish broth can be  stored in the refrigerator for up  to  3 days, or frozen for   up to 3  months.

Ingredients:

 1  lb duck meat, trimmed and  finely diced
 2 tsp soy sauce
 1 tsp Chinese wine  (or substitute sherry)
 1 tsp cornstarch
 1 tsp sesame oil
 1 tsp grated  ginger
 2 green  onions,  finely chopped
 1 egg
  1  package dumpling wrappers  (approximately 50  wrappers)
 1 tbsp olive oil
  1/2 cup chicken broth

Instructions:

1. In a  large  bowl, combine all  ingredients except  for dumpling wrappers, olive oil, and chicken  broth.  Mix well.

2.  Take a dumpling wrapper and place a small amount of the  filling in the  center. Wet  the edges of the wrapper with  water and fold  in half to form a half-moon shape. Press the  edges together to seal.

3. In  a large pan, bring olive oil to medium heat. Add dumplings in  a single layer and cook for 2-3  minutes until the bottoms are golden brown.

4. Add chicken broth to  the  pan and  cover with a lid. Cook for another 3-4 minutes until  the dumplings are cooked through.

5. Serve  with soy sauce and chili  oil for dipping.

Here is a recipe for Split Pea Soup with Roasted  Fennel  and Lobster Salad:

Ingredients:

For the split pea soup:
1 pound split peas,  rinsed and  picked  over
1 medium onion, chopped
2 medium carrots, chopped
2  stalks  of celery,  chopped
1 garlic  clove, minced
1/4 cup olive oil
1/4 cup dry white wine
4 cups chicken  or vegetable broth
1/2 teaspoon fresh  thyme leaves, chopped
1/2   teaspoon fresh marjoram or  oregano,  chopped
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon ground black  pepper

For  the  roasted  fennel:
2 medium fennel bulbs, trimmed and cut into  1/2-inch-thick  slices
1/4  cup  olive oil
1/4  teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper

For the lobster salad:
1  pound cooked  lobster  meat, chopped
1/4 cup mayonnaise
1 tablespoon lemon juice
1 tablespoon chopped fresh chives
1 tablespoon chopped fresh tarragon
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper

Instructions:
1. To  make  the split pea soup,  in a large pot, combine the  split peas,  onion, carrots, celery, garlic, olive oil, white wine, broth, thyme,  marjoram, salt, and pepper. Bring  to a boil over medium-high heat, then reduce the  heat  to  low, cover, and simmer until the peas are very  soft  and beginning to fall apart, about 1 hour.
2. Meanwhile, to make the   roasted fennel, preheat the oven to 400F (200C). On a baking sheet, toss the fennel slices with the olive oil, salt,  and pepper. Roast until tender and lightly browned, about 20  minutes.
3. To make  the lobster salad, in a medium  bowl, combine the lobster meat,  mayonnaise, lemon juice, chives, tarragon,  salt, and pepper.
4. To serve, ladle the  soup into bowls and top with a  spoonful of the lobster  salad and some roasted fennel. Enjoy!

Ingredients
 8 each  bone-in chicken thighs (about 3  pounds)
 Kosher salt and  black  pepper
 2 cups chicken  broth
 2 cups  water
   cup white vinegar
  2 tablespoons olive oil
 4 medium  garlic cloves, peeled  and smashed
 1 large shallot, finely chopped  (about  cup)
 Leaves from   3 sprigs fresh thyme,  plus  1  sprig
 1 pound mustard greens, washed, dried, and torn into bite-size pieces
   cup  heavy cream

Instructions
1. Season the chicken  with salt and pepper. In  a large bowl, combine the broth, water, vinegar, olive oil, garlic,  chopped  shallot,  and thyme  leaves; set aside.
2. In a large Dutch oven  or  heavy pot, layer the chicken thighs, greens, and thyme   sprig, alternating and  starting  and ending with the greens. Pour the broth  mixture  over the top and  press gently on the greens to submerge them.
3. Bring  the mixture to  a boil over medium-high heat. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and simmer for about 20-25 minutes, or until the chicken is cooked through and the greens are wilted.
4. Transfer the chicken and greens to a platter using a   slotted spoon. Cover loosely with foil to keep warm.
5. Increase the heat to medium and bring the liquid to a boil. Cook, stirring  occasionally, until reduced  by  about half. Stir in the heavy cream   and  return to a boil. Cook, stirring, for about  2 minutes, or until   thickened. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
6. Pour the sauce  over the chicken   and greens. Serve.

Ingredients:

- 1  pound beef sirloin, trimmed and sliced against  the grain into 1/4-inch-thick  slices
- 1/2  cup low-sodium soy sauce
- 1/3  cup packed dark brown sugar
- 1 tablespoon   toasted  sesame oil
- 1 tablespoon    rice vinegar
- 1 tablespoon honey
- 1 teaspoon cornstarch
- 1/2 teaspoon crushed   red pepper
- 1/4 teaspoon ground  ginger
-  1/4 teaspoon ground white pepper
- 3/4 cup chicken broth
- 2 tablespoons  chopped green onion
-  1 tablespoon chopped fresh cilantro
- 1 teaspoon grated orange zest

Instructions:

1. Combine the first 9 ingredients in  a medium bowl, stirring with  a whisk.
2. Combine beef and soy sauce mixture in a zip-top  plastic bag, and marinate in the refrigerator  1 hour, turning bag occasionally.
3. Place a large nonstick skillet over  medium-high heat until hot. Add half of beef mixture, and  stir-fry 1 minute or  until  outside surface of  beef  is  no   longer pink. (Do not overcook.) Remove   from skillet. Repeat procedure with remaining  beef mixture.
4. Add broth to skillet, and bring to  a boil. Cook until reduced to 1/4 cup (about 2 minutes).
5. Return beef to skillet; stir to coat.
6. Place beef on a serving platter, and sprinkle  with   green onions, cilantro, and orange zest.

Ingredients:
1 fish head (about 1 lb/455 g) or fish bones
1 onion,  roughly chopped
3 cloves garlic, crushed
2 lemons, 1 sliced  and 1 halved
1/3 cup/10 g fresh parsley stems
1 tbsp black peppercorns
1/2  tsp  salt

Instructions:
1. In a large saucepan, combine all ingredients with 4  cups/1 liter water and bring to a boil over high heat.
2. Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for  20 minutes.
3. Remove from the   heat and strain the broth through a fine-mesh strainer.
4. Use  the broth  immediately, or  let   it cool  completely  before storing it in the  refrigerator for up to 4 days or in  the freezer for up to  3 months.

Note: You can add additional ingredients to the broth, such as carrots,  celery,  or  herbs, to enhance  the  flavor.

1 1/2   cups almond flour (or other whole-wheat flour)

3  tablespoons coconut oil, melted

1 teaspoon  baking  powder

1  tablespoon vanilla  extract

1  cup powdered sugar

1 egg

1/4 cup coconut milk

1/8 teaspoon salt

Preheat oven to 350 degrees  F. Grease and flour two 9 round cake pans. In a large bowl, whisk together  the almond flour, coconut oil, baking powder, vanilla extract, and powdered   sugar until well combined. Add in the egg and  mix until  just combined. Stir in  the  coconut milk and salt. Pour batter into prepared pan(s). Bake for 20 minutes or until toothpick inserted  comes out clean. Let  cool completely before frosting.

I made  these donuts with my KitchenAid  stand mixer. I used the dough hook attachment on  the machine to knead the dough for  about 5  minutes. The dough was very sticky but not too hard to work with. After that,  I  added  the coconut  milk and  salt and mixed it up again. Then I added the egg and beat it until smooth. It took me  about 3 more  minutes to get the dough to come together. Once it did,  I  rolled  it out onto parchment paper and cut it  into rounds. I then placed them   on a  sheet  pan  lined  with waxed paper. I let them sit at room  temperature  for an  hour before  frosting.

These are  delicious! They were moist and soft and tasted like they had been baked in the oven. I would  definitely make  this again.

"Smoked Ham"

1 pound smoked  ham

1/2 cup  butter

1/2 cup  flour

1/2   cup   sugar

1/2  teaspoon  salt

Instructions:

Ingredients (for 6 servings)

2 1/4 pound  ground beef

1 small onion, finely chopped

6 ribs  celery sliced thinly

3 bay  leaves

1 medium potato, peeled and cubed

2 large carrots cut into   inch pieces

2 stalks celery, coarsely shredded (optional)

2 tablespoons dry taco seasoning mix

Pinch of cayenne pepper ("add in to spice mix if  you   can't  bear it")

Salt & freshly ground black pepper

Directions

Brown meat in a small saucepan or  skillet over low heat until no longer  pink.

Meanwhile, chop onions,  carrots and celery into  bite-size pieces.  Set  aside.

In the same large   pot  with meat, cook remaining ingredients on high while stirring occasionally until potatoes are fork tender. Add  seasonings after the meat  has  cooked through.

Serve with homemade  "Texas Toast", sour  cream,  chopped black  olives, crackers, apple cider vinegar,  and more grated cheese for serving!
"Carbonara  is a tomato-based Italian  dish that's a dish made with    pasta (usually linguine), but with a topping of cream and lots of green vegetables. It's usually topped with mozzarella cheese.

Ingredients:
1 pound ground duck
1/2 cup chopped onion
1/4 cup chopped celery
1/4 cup chopped green bell pepper
1/4 cup all-purpose flour
1 teaspoon salt
1/4 teaspoon black pepper
1 (10.75 ounce) can  condensed   cream  of  chicken soup
1/2 cup water
1 (12  ounce) package frozen mixed vegetables
1 (14.1 ounce) package refrigerated  buttermilk biscuits

Instructions:
1.  Preheat  oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C).
2. In a large bowl, mix  together ground duck, onion, celery, green  bell  pepper, flour, salt, and black pepper.
3. In  a small bowl, whisk together cream  of chicken soup and water. Pour over duck  mixture, and mix  well.
4. Stir in  frozen mixed vegetables.
5. Grease a 9x13  inch baking dish. Separate biscuits,  and place on top of duck mixture.
6.  Bake for 20  minutes, or  until biscuits  are golden  brown.

Ingredients:

1 lb. dried  split peas, soaked overnight

1  large fennel bulb, diced

1 small onion,   diced

3 cloves garlic, minced

4 cups chicken or  vegetable stock

2 bay leaves

1/2 teaspoon  dried  thyme

Salt and  black pepper to taste

1  (1 lb.) lobster   tail, cooked  and diced

1/2  cup mayonnaise

1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice

Ground cayenne pepper to taste

1 head Boston lettuce, shredded

1/4  cup chopped fresh parsley

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).

2. In a large pot,  combine split peas, fennel, onion,  garlic, chicken stock, bay leaves, thyme,  salt, and black pepper. Bring to  a boil, reduce heat to low, and simmer  for 1 1/2 hours, or until split  peas are very soft.

3. Remove from heat, and   discard bay  leaves. Puree soup in a  blender  or food processor, and return to pot.

4.  In a  small bowl,  combine lobster, mayonnaise, lemon juice, and cayenne pepper.

5. To serve, ladle soup into individual bowls, and top  with lobster salad and   shredded lettuce. Sprinkle with chopped parsley.

Ingredients:

1 (3-pound)  chicken, cut into 8 pieces

Salt and freshly ground black pepper

1/4 cup all-purpose  flour

2 tablespoons olive  oil

1 large  onion, halved and sliced

1/2 cup chicken broth

1/2  cup white vinegar

1/4 cup honey

1 teaspoon  dried thyme

1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper

1/2 pound  greens (such as Swiss chard, kale, or collards), tough stems removed, leaves chopped

Directions:

1. Season chicken with salt and pepper. Dredge in flour, shaking off any excess.

2. In   a large  Dutch oven or other  heavy pot,  heat oil over medium-high heat. Add chicken and cook until browned, about 5 minutes per side.

3. Add onion and  cook until  softened, about    5 minutes.

4. Add chicken broth, vinegar, honey, thyme, and cayenne, and bring to a  boil.

5.  Add greens and cook until wilted, about  5  minutes.

6. Reduce heat to low and  simmer, covered, until chicken is cooked through  and sauce is thickened, about   30 minutes.

7. Serve  over  cooked rice or other   grain.

Ingredients:

1 pound beef sirloin, cut  into thin strips

1/2 cup all-purpose flour

2 tablespoons cornstarch

1  teaspoon salt

1/2 teaspoon baking soda

1/4 teaspoon black  pepper

1/4  cup  vegetable oil

1/2 cup orange juice

1/4 cup light  soy sauce

1  tablespoon rice  vinegar

1 tablespoon  sugar

1 tablespoon ketchup

1 tablespoon chili paste with garlic

1 teaspoon grated orange peel

Directions:

1. In a large resealable plastic bag, combine flour,  cornstarch, salt, baking soda and pepper.  Add beef strips,  a few at a  time, and shake to coat.

2. In  a  large skillet or wok, heat  oil over medium-high  heat. Add beef strips;  stir-fry for 3-4 minutes   or until beef is no longer pink.   Remove  and drain on paper towels.

3.  In a small saucepan,  combine the orange juice, soy sauce, vinegar, sugar, ketchup, chili paste and orange peel. Bring to a boil.

4. Add beef strips;  cook and stir for 2-3 minutes or until sauce  is  thickened.

Ingredients:

1 tablespoon olive  oil

1 onion,  chopped

3 cloves garlic,  minced

1  carrot, chopped

1 celery   stalk, chopped

1/2 teaspoon dried  thyme

1/2 teaspoon dried basil

1/4 teaspoon dried oregano

1/4 teaspoon dried  rosemary

1 bay leaf

1/2 cup white wine

4 cups chicken broth

1 (14.5 ounce) can diced tomatoes, undrained

1 (8 ounce) can tomato   sauce

1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley

1/4 cup chopped fresh basil

1/2 teaspoon salt

1/4 teaspoon black pepper

1 pound cod fillets,  cut into 1-inch pieces

1/4 cup all-purpose flour

2 tablespoons olive oil

1/4 cup grated Parmesan cheese

Directions:

In a large saucepan, heat 1 tablespoon olive oil  over medium heat. Add onion, garlic, carrot, celery, thyme, basil, oregano, rosemary,   and bay leaf; cook and stir  until vegetables  are tender,  about 10 minutes.

Stir  in wine,  chicken   broth,   diced tomatoes with their juice, tomato  sauce, parsley, basil, salt, and black pepper. Bring to  a  boil; reduce heat to low and simmer for  30 minutes.

Meanwhile,  in a shallow bowl, toss cod pieces  with flour. In a  large skillet, heat 2 tablespoons olive oil over medium-high heat. Add cod; cook and stir until  fish is  opaque, about  3  minutes.

Remove bay leaf from  soup. Stir in cod and Parmesan cheese. Cook just  until heated through,  about 5 minutes.

Ingredients for Duck  Dumplings:

For the Filling:
- 1 whole duck
- 1 tablespoon soy sauce
- 1  teaspoon Chinese five-spice powder
- 1  teaspoon sugar 
- 1/4  cup hoisin sauce
-  2 green onions,  finely chopped
- 1/2 cup diced water chestnuts
- 1  garlic clove, minced
- 1 tablespoon grated fresh ginger

For the Dumplings:
- 40 dumpling wrappers
- Small bowl of  water, for assembling dumplings
-  canola oil, for frying

For the Dipping sauce:
- 1/2 cup soy sauce
- 1/4 cup rice vinegar
- 2  teaspoons  sesame oil
- 1 teaspoon sugar 
- 1  green onion,  chopped

Instructions:

1. Preheat  your oven to 350F (175C).  Place  the duck   on a rack in a roasting  pan and season with soy  sauce, sugar, and Chinese five-spice. Roast the   duck in  the  oven for about 2 hours or until  the internal temperature reaches   165F  (75C).

2. While the duck is roasting, prepare the dipping sauce  by  whisking together soy sauce, rice vinegar, sesame oil, sugar and chopped green onion in a small bowl. Set aside.

3. When  the  duck  is done, remove  it from oven and set aside until  cool enough to handle. Shred the duck meat, discarding the skin  and bones.

4. In a large bowl, combine  shredded duck meat, hoisin  sauce, chopped  green onions, diced water chestnuts, minced garlic and grated ginger. Stir until well combined.

5. Lay out the dumpling wrappers out  on  a clean work  surface. Scoop about 1 tablespoon of the  duck  mixture onto  the center of each wrapper.

6. Dip your finger in the bowl of water and run it around the edge  of each dumpling wrapper. Fold the  wrapper over the filling  to create   a semi-circle, and press the edges together  to seal.

7. Heat a large pan over medium  heat and add  a little bit  of oil. Add the dumplings  in batches, ensuring they  dont touch  each other, and pan-fry until the bottoms  are golden brown,  about 3-4 minutes.

8. Add a   few tablespoons of water  to  the pan, cover and let dumplings steam for another 2 minutes or until the water has evaporated.  Repeat with remaining dumplings.

9.  Serve duck dumplings   hot  with the dipping  sauce.

Ingredients for Split Pea Soup:

1. 1 1/2   cups  dried split peas
2. 1 tablespoon olive oil
3. 1  white onion, chopped
4. 1 fennel bulb, chopped (fronds  set  aside)
5. 2 cloves garlic, minced
6.  7 cups  vegetable broth
7. Salt and black pepper to taste

Ingredients for Roasted Fennel:
1.  2  fennel bulbs, cut into quarters
2. 2 tablespoons  olive  oil
3. Salt and pepper  to taste

Ingredients for Lobster Salad:
1. 1 lb cooked lobster meat,   diced
2. 3 tablespoons mayonnaise
3.  1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice
4. 2  stalks of celery,  finely chopped
5. Salt and pepper to taste

Instructions:

1. Start by preheating your oven  to 400F (200C) for the roasted  fennel.

2. To  make the split pea soup, heat oil  in a large pot or  dutch oven over medium heat.

3.   Add the onion, chopped fennel, and garlic. Saut until softened, about  10 minutes.

4. Add split peas and vegetable broth, bring  to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer, until  peas are  soft, usually for about one hour.

5. While the soup is simmering, prepare the  roasted fennel. Toss fennel  quarters in olive oil, salt,  and pepper. Spread out on a  foil-lined baking sheet and roast for 25-30 minutes until  tender and  caramelized.

6.  To make the   lobster salad,  combine the diced lobster, mayonnaise, lemon juice, celery, salt, and pepper -  mixing  well. Refrigerate until needed.

7. When the  split peas are  soft,  use an immersion  blender  to puree the soup until smooth. Add seasoning as needed.

8. To serve,  ladle the soup into bowls, top with a spoonful  of lobster salad and a   piece of roasted fennel. 

Enjoy this comfort dish packed with  exciting flavors and textures!

Ingredients:

-  4 chicken thighs
- 4 chicken drumsticks
- Salt and Pepper to taste
- 3 tablespoons olive  oil
-  1 medium onion, finely chopped
- 3 garlic cloves, finely chopped
- 1  tablespoon tomato paste
- 2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
- 1/2 cup red wine vinegar
- 4 cups low-sodium chicken broth
- 1 bay leaf
- 1  bunch of mixed greens  (such  as kale  and collards), ribs and stems removed,  leaves cut  into  bite-size pieces
- Fresh parsley for garnish 

Instructions:

1. Season chicken with salt and   pepper. 

2. In a large,  heavy pot or  Dutch  oven, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat. Add chicken, skin side down, and cook until browned, about 5  minutes on each side.  Transfer the chicken to  a  plate.

3. Reduce heat to medium. Add the onions into the pot and cook,  stirring occasionally,  until golden brown, about 8-10  minutes.

4. Add  the garlic and cook for another 2  minutes, stirring continuously to avoid burning. 

5.  Add the tomato paste  and flour into the pot  and stir for  about a minute until a thick paste forms. 

6. Stir in vinegar, then   add broth,  bay leaf  and chicken  with any accumulated juices. Bring to  a boil, reduce heat, and  partially cover. Let it simmer until chicken is cooked through,  about 40-50  minutes.

7. Add mixed  greens to pot and cook, stirring, until  wilted, about 5-7 minutes. Season with more  salt and  pepper, if desired.

8. Garnish with  fresh parsley and  serve with crusty bread, if you like.  Enjoy  your Vinegar-Braised Chicken With Greens.

SZECHUAN CRISPY ORANGE BEEF RECIPE

Ingredients:

- 1 pound boneless beef  steak, (sirloin or tenderloin),  thinly sliced
- 2 oranges,  zest and juice
- 1/4 cup soy sauce
- 1/4 cup white vinegar
- 1/4  cup granulated white sugar
- 1 tbsp  cornstarch
- 1 tsp  Szechuan pepper, crushed
- 2 cloves   garlic, minced
- 1 tbsp fresh ginger,  minced
- 2 cups vegetable  oil for frying
- 1/2 cup cornstarch for dredging
- 1 red bell pepper, thinly sliced
- 4 green  onions, sliced
- 1 tsp red pepper flakes (optional for added  heat)

Instructions:

1. In a bowl, combine soy sauce, vinegar, sugar, orange juice, and  orange zest. Stir  until sugar  is completely dissolved.

2. Take half of this mixture and marinate the thinly  sliced beef in it for  at least one hour, covered  in the refrigerator.

3. Mix 1    tbsp cornstarch into the remaining sauce,  stir well and  set   aside.

4. Drain the beef from  the marinade and pat   dry. Dredge  each  piece in  cornstarch, ensuring each piece is thoroughly coated.

5. Heat the vegetable oil in a wok or deep skillet  over  high heat. Once  hot  but not smoking, add the beef slices  and fry them until they are crispy and  golden brown.  Do not overload the pan, you  may need to do this in batches.

6. Remove the  crispy beef slices  using a slotted  spoon and place them on a paper  towel    to get rid of excess oil.

7. In a separate pan, saut minced garlic, ginger, and crushed Szechuan pepper for about  1 minute over medium heat or   until fragrant.

8. Add  the  sliced bell peppers to the  pan and  stir-fry for a minute.

9. Pour the remainder  of the orange sauce into the  pan and let it simmer. The sauce should thicken because of the  cornstarch.

10. Once the  sauce is thickened, add  the crispy beef,  sliced green onions, and red pepper   flakes (if using).  Toss  all these  together until the beef is coated with sauce.

11. Serve your Szechuan Crispy Orange Beef hot with a side of steamed rice or noodles.

Enjoy your spicy, tangy, and  crispy Szechuan dish!

Recipe  for Fish  Broth:

Ingredients:

1. 1 lb fish  bones or fish head
2. 2 tablespoons vegetable oil 
3. 2 onions - chopped 
4. 2 carrots - chopped 
5. 2 sticks celery - chopped 
6. 3  cloves garlic - chopped 
7. 1 cup  dry white wine 
8. 2  quarts water  
9. 1-2 bay leaves  
10. 1 teaspoon black peppercorns 
11. A bunch of fresh parsley
12. Salt to taste

Instructions:

1. Rinse the fish bones or head under cold water. Make sure to remove any  blood, as it  can make  your broth cloudy.

2. Heat the vegetable oil in  a large pot over medium heat. Add in  the onions, carrots, celery, and garlic,  and saut them for about 3-4 minutes or   until they start to soften.

3. Once the  vegetables  are soft, add  in the fish  bones or  fish head to the pot and stir well.  Allow it to cook with the vegetables for another  3-4 minutes.

4. After the fish and vegetables have cooked together, pour in  the white wine  and  turn up the heat  to bring it  to a simmer. Let  it simmer for about 2-3 minutes to allow the alcohol to evaporate.

5. Then add the fresh water, parsley,  black peppercorns, and  bay leaves to the pot.  Bring  the mixture to    a boil. 

6. Reduce the heat to  low  to  maintain a gentle   simmer. Cover the pot but  leave the lid ajar slightly. Let it simmer for about 2.5-3 hours. 

7.  Skim off any foam that rises to the surface periodically during the simmering process.

8. After  it  has  simmered, strain your fish broth through a fine mesh strainer into another pot  or  container. Discard the solids.

9. Taste  the broth and add salt, if needed.  

10.  Use  your homemade fish  broth immediately, or let  it cool  then store it in  a sealed container in  your refrigerator for up  to  1 week, or freeze for up to 6 months. 

This fish broth  can  be  used as  the base for many different soup, chowder and stew recipes, or you could simply enjoy it hot with   a bit of fresh chopped  parsley   on top. Enjoy!

Title: Meatloaf for Meatloaf Haters

Introduction:
Are you tired  of   the same old meatloaf recipes that are heavy, dense, and just plain boring? Do  you have a meatloaf hater in your household who refuses  to touch the stuff? Fear not, we've got a solution for you!  This recipe for Meatloaf for Meatloaf  Haters is  light, flavorful, and  perfect for those who  think  they don't like meatloaf.

* 1/2 cup breadcrumbs (preferably Panko)

* 1 tsp dried  oregano
* Salt and pepper to taste
*  1/4 cup chopped onion

* 1/4 cup chopped bacon (optional)

Instructions:

1. Preheat  your  oven to 375F (190C).

3. Add the chopped onion, bell pepper, mushrooms, and bacon (if using) to the meat    mixture and  mix again  until they are evenly distributed.
4. Transfer the mixture to a loaf  pan lined with  parchment paper  or  aluminum foil.  Smooth the top  and create a small indentation down the center of the  loaf to help the meat cook evenly.
5. Bake  the meatloaf for 45-50 minutes,  or until

Sure! Here's a recipe for Caesar-Roasted Fish:

Ingredients:

* 4 fish fillets (such as cod, halibut, or  snapper)
* 2  tablespoons olive   oil
* 1/4 cup Caesar dressing
* 1/4 cup  lemon juice
* 2 cloves garlic, minced
* 1 teaspoon dried thyme
* Salt and   pepper to taste
* Fresh  parsley, chopped (optional)

Instructions:

1. Preheat the oven to 400F  (200C).
2.  Line  a baking sheet with  aluminum foil or  parchment paper.
3. Place the fish  fillets on the  prepared baking sheet.
4. Drizzle  the olive oil over the fish fillets, then brush them evenly with the Caesar  dressing.
5. Sprinkle the  lemon juice, garlic,  and thyme over the  top of each fillet. Season with salt and  pepper to taste.
6. Roast the fish in the preheated oven for  12-15  minutes per inch  of thickness, or until it reaches an internal temperature  of 145F  (63C).
7. Remove the fish from the oven and garnish with  chopped fresh  parsley, if  desired.
8. Serve immediately and enjoy!

This recipe is a delicious twist on traditional roasted fish, using Caesar dressing instead of lemon butter or herbs. The creamy, tangy  flavor of the dressing pairs perfectly with the  rich  flavors of the fish, while the lemon juice adds a  bright   burst of citrus. You can serve   this dish with   your favorite sides,  such as  roasted vegetables or quinoa. Enjoy!

Sure!   Here's a simple recipe  for squash and apple  soup:

Ingredients:

*  1 medium-sized butternut squash, peeled and  diced  into small pieces (about 2 cups)
* 3 apples, cored and chopped into small  pieces
* 4 tablespoons unsalted butter or oil
* 2  onions, chopped (about 1  cup)
* 3 cloves garlic, minced
*  2 teaspoons cumin powder
* 1/2 teaspoon nutmeg powder
* Salt and pepper   to   taste
*  Stock   (homemade or low-sodium store-bought)  as  needed
* Freshly  squeezed lemon juice (optional)

Instructions:

1. Preheat your oven  to  400F (200C). Place the diced squash on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper,  drizzle with about  2 tablespoons of butter or oil, and season with salt, pepper, and cumin powder. Roast in the preheated oven until tender and lightly browned, stirring occasionally, for about 45 minutes.
2.  While the squash is roasting, heat  another 2 tablespoons of butter or oil  over medium heat in a pot. Add the chopped onions,  cook until softened and translucent, about 8-10 minutes. Add  the minced garlic and saut for an additional minute.
3. Remove from  heat and  let  cool slightly, then process the roasted squash, onions, garlic, and any accumulated pan  drippings into smaller chunks  using  an immersion  blender  or transfer them to a blender   or  food processor. Blend  until smooth.
4. Transfer the mixture back to the pot if  you  used a blender or food processor and add enough stock to cover all  the ingredients.   Bring to a simmer over medium heat. Reduce heat  to low and Cook until heated through,  57 minutes. Season with salt, nutmeg, and more  cumin to taste

Sure! Here's a recipe for Purple Potato Mash Up:

Ingredients:

* 3-4 large  purple potatoes, peeled and  chopped into 1-inch cubes
* 1/4 cup milk  or half-and-half
* 2  tablespoons butter
*  1/2 teaspoon salt
*  1/4  teaspoon black pepper
* 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder
* 1/4 teaspoon paprika
* 1/4 cup grated cheddar cheese (optional)
*  Chopped fresh herbs,  such as  parsley or chives (optional)

Instructions:

1. Place the  chopped potatoes in a  large pot and add enough cold water to cover them. Bring to a   boil over high heat, then reduce the heat to medium-low  and simmer for 15-20 minutes, or until the potatoes  are  tender when  pierced with a fork.
2. Drain   the potatoes and return them to   the pot. Add the milk, butter,  salt, black pepper,  garlic powder, and paprika. Mash the potatoes with  a potato masher  or a fork until  they're  smooth and creamy.
3.  If using, stir in the grated cheddar cheese until it's  fully  incorporated.
4. Taste  and adjust the seasoning as needed.
5.  Serve the  mashed potatoes hot, garnished with chopped fresh  herbs if desired. Enjoy!

Note: You can also add some diced cooked bacon, ham, or sauted onions and bell  peppers to the mashed potatoes for added flavor and  texture. Experiment  with different combinations  to  find your  favorite variation of this delicious side dish!

1 (8 ounce) package spaghetti, cooked and  drained
2  tablespoons olive oil
3  cloves garlic, minced
1/4 cup chopped onion
1  pound ground beef
1 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon black pepper
1/2 teaspoon dried oregano
1/2 teaspoon crushed red  pepper flakes
1 (6 ounce) can  tomato paste

Heat the  olive oil in a large  skillet over medium heat; cook and stir the garlic and onions  until tender. Toss the sauce  with the pasta  and sprinkle with Parmesan  cheese before serving.

Sure! Here's a   simple   recipe to make Blistered Okra with  Dill-Coriander Lebneh.

Ingredients:

* 2 cups okra,  washed and chopped into bite-sized pieces
* Olive oil
* Salt and  black pepper  (to taste)
* Fresh lemon juice  (optional)

For the dill-coriander  lebneh:

*   1 cup  plain  yogurt (Greek or Middle Eastern style)
*  cup fresh dill leaves, finely chopped
*  cup coriander leaves, finely chopped
* 1 clove garlic, minced
* 1 tbsp  olive  oil
*  Salt and black pepper (to taste)
* Zest of one lemon  (optional)

Instructions:

To make the blistered okra, heat a large skillet over  medium-high heat. Add  about 2 tablespoons of olive oil  and season with  salt and black pepper to  taste. Once  heated through, add in the okra and  toss to coat  in oil and spices.  Cook  for 4-5 minutes on each side or until  the  okra is tender  and slightly charred. Squeeze  extra lemon juice  on top if desired and serve hot  with  dill-coriander lebneh on the side.

To make the dill-coriander  lebnek, place the yogurt in a strainer set inside  a  mixing bowl. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight to allow any excess liquid to  drain out. In a small blender, combine the chopped herbs, garlic, olive  oil, and seasonings to taste. Pour  this mixture over the  yogurt and stir to combine. You can continue  to  mix by hand or use the  blender to puree until it  reaches your desired consistency.  If you  prefer a smoother texture, you can also strain off some of the solids using cheesecloth or a  muslin cloth. Serve chilled alongside  the blistered okra.

Classic Buttermilk Biscuits (Nytimes)

Ingredients:
- 2 cups all-purpose   flour
- 1  tablespoon baking powder
- 3/4  teaspoon salt
- 1/2  cup  unsalted butter, cold, cut into small cubes
-   3/4 cup buttermilk
- 1  large egg
- 1 tablespoon sugar
- 1 teaspoon baking  soda
-  1/4 teaspoon cream of tartar

Instructions:
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the  flour,  baking powder, and salt.
2. Add  the cold butter  cubes to the dry ingredients  and mix  with your hands or a  pastry cutter until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
3.  In a separate  bowl, whisk  together  the buttermilk, egg, sugar, baking soda, and cream of tartar.
4. Pour  the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix until  just combined.
5. On a lightly floured  surface,  knead the  dough until it comes together, then roll it out to about 1 inch thickness.
6. Use a biscuit cutter to  cut out the   biscuits and place  them on a baking sheet lined  with parchment paper.
7.  Bake at 425F for 12-15 minutes, or until the   biscuits are golden brown on top and bottom.
8. Serve warm with your favorite toppings, such as honey, butter, or jam. Enjoy!

Poached Pears with Saffron Broth  Recipe

Ingredients:
- 4 ripe pears
- 1 cup water
- 1  cup white wine
-  1/4 cup sugar
- 1 cinnamon stick
- 5 whole cloves
-  1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg
- 1/4 teaspoon salt
-  1/4 cup   freshly  squeezed lemon juice
- 1/4 cup chopped fresh  parsley
- 1/4  cup chopped fresh  mint
- 1/4 cup chopped fresh dill
- Saffron threads,  for garnish

Instructions:

1.  In a large  saucepan, combine the water, white wine, sugar, cinnamon stick, cloves, nutmeg,  and salt.  Bring the mixture to  a boil over medium-high heat, stirring to dissolve the sugar.
2.  Reduce the heat to medium-low  and simmer for 10 minutes.
3. Meanwhile, peel, core, and halve the  pears. Arrange the pears, cut side up, in a large heatproof dish or baking  dish.
4. Pour the hot broth over the pears, making sure they are completely submerged.   Cover the dish  with   aluminum foil and let  it sit at room temperature for  at least 2 hours,  or refrigerate overnight.
5. To serve, remove the pears from the broth with a slotted spoon and drain well. Arrange the pears  on a serving platter and pour the broth over them.
6. Garnish with  fresh  parsley, mint,  and dill.  Sprinkle  saffron threads over the top  for added color and flavor.
7. Serve immediately  and enjoy   your  delicious Poached Pears  with Saffron Broth!

Asparagus  Sheaves  Kambu Recipe

Ingredients:

* 1 pound asparagus,  trimmed and cut into 1-inch pieces
* 1/2 cup kambu  (Japanese dried seaweed)
* 4 cups water
* 1 tablespoon soy sauce
*  1  tablespoon mirin
* 1 tablespoon   sugar
* 1 teaspoon grated ginger
* 2 cloves garlic, minced
* 1/4 cup chopped green  onions
* Salt and pepper to taste

Instructions:

1.  In a   large  pot, bring the water  to a boil. Add   the kambu and let it soak for  5 minutes.
2. Add the asparagus to the pot and cook for 5-7 minutes, or until tender.
3. In a small bowl, whisk together the soy sauce, mirin,  sugar, ginger, and  garlic.
4. Pour the sauce over  the asparagus and kambu and stir to coat.
5. Cook for an additional 2-3  minutes, or until the   sauce has thickened.
6. Remove  the pot from the heat and  stir in the chopped  green onions.
7. Season with salt  and  pepper to taste.
8. Serve  hot and enjoy!

In this article you'll learn what  I consider an excellent way to make delicious stuffed peppers, without any precooking required at your end (or mine!). These  are made  in exactly four easy steps and serve 6 people as main course  or 12-15   appetizers.. Ingredients:
- 1 1/2  cups  all-purpose flour
- 1/2 cup  cornstarch
-  1/2 cup powdered  sugar
-  1/2 cup cold unsalted butter,  cut into small pieces
-  2 large egg yolks
-  1/4  cup milk
- 2  teaspoons vanilla extract
- Food coloring (optional)

Instructions:

1. Preheat the oven to 325F (160C). Line a  baking sheet  with parchment paper.

2. In a  medium bowl,  whisk together the flour and cornstarch. Add the powdered sugar and mix well.

3. Using a pastry cutter or  your fingers, work  the  butter into the flour  mixture  until it resembles coarse crumbs.

4. In a separate bowl,  whisk together the egg  yolks, milk, and vanilla extract. Add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients and mix until a  dough forms.

5. If desired, add a few drops of food coloring to  the dough and mix until the color is   evenly distributed.

6. Roll out the  dough on a floured surface  to a thickness of  about 1/4 inch (6 mm). Cut out shapes  using cookie cutters, and place  them on the  prepared baking sheet.

7. Bake  the petit fours for 15-20  minutes, or until  they are lightly golden brown. Remove  them from the  oven and let them  cool completely on the baking sheet.

8.  Once the petit fours  are cool, you can decorate them with  additional powdered sugar,  frosting, or  other toppings of  your choice.

9. Store the  petit fours in an airtight container for up to 3 days. Enjoy!

Ingredients:
- 4 large   leeks, white and light green  parts only, thinly sliced
- 6 large  eggs
- 1/2 cup grated parmesan cheese
- 1/2 teaspoon salt
- 1/4 teaspoon black pepper
- 2  tablespoons unsalted butter

Instructions:
1. Preheat the oven to 350F.  
2.   Heat a large skillet  over  medium-high heat. 
3.  Add the butter to the skillet and let it  melt. 
4.  Add the leeks  to the skillet and saut until they  are soft and  translucent, about 5 minutes. 
5. In a medium bowl, whisk together  the eggs,  parmesan cheese, salt, and  black pepper.  
6. Pour  the egg  mixture   over the  leeks in  the skillet and let it  cook for 2-3 minutes, until the edges start  to set. 
7.  Place the skillet in  the oven and bake for 10-12 minutes, until the frittata is set and golden brown on top. 
8. Remove the skillet from the oven and let the frittata cool for a few minutes. 
9. Slice the frittata  into wedges and serve  warm. 
10. Enjoy!

Ingredients:
- 1 lb textured vegetable protein (TVP)
- 2 tsp cumin
-  1 tsp turmeric
- 1 tsp paprika
- 1/2 tsp coriander
-  1/2 tsp garlic powder
- 1/4 tsp salt
- 2 tbsp olive oil
- 1/4 onion, chopped
- 1/2 cup breadcrumbs
- 1 tbsp  chopped fresh parsley

Instructions:

1.  Preheat the oven to   375F.

2. In a  large  mixing bowl, crumble the  TVP and add the cumin, turmeric, paprika, coriander, garlic powder, and salt. Mix well.

3. In a pan, heat  the olive oil and  saut the   chopped onion until softened. Add the onion  to the  TVP mixture and combine well.

4. Add 2/3 cup  of water to the  mixture and stir until well  combined. Let  it sit for 5-10 minutes until  the TVP absorbs the water.

5. On a lightly floured surface, knead the mixture for  a few minutes until it becomes smooth and pliable.

6.  Divide the mixture  into 4 equal  portions  and  shape each   portion into a cylinder.

7. In a shallow dish, mix the breadcrumbs and parsley together. Coat each cylinder in the breadcrumb mixture.

8. Place  the cylinders on a baking  sheet lined  with parchment paper and bake for  25-30 minutes, until golden brown.

9. Let the "lamb" cylinders rest for a  few minutes before slicing them  into  rounds.

10. Serve the   Cumin Un-Lamb  with your favorite sides  such as rice,  vegetables, or  pita bread.  Enjoy!

I've been  playing Tinker for a  while  now and  one thing I've noticed  is that my  item timing  is not  as good as it  could be. I  often find myself  struggling to  get my core items   at the right time, which can really impact my effectiveness  in team fights   and split pushing. 

After doing  some research and  experimenting, I've found  a few tips that have helped me  improve my  item timing with Tinker. 

Firstly, it's important to  prioritize farming efficiency. Tinker is  a hero that  relies heavily  on gold and experience, so  you need to  make sure  you're maximizing your farm.  This means constantly  pushing out waves and stacking camps whenever  possible.  

Secondly, you should try to minimize downtime. Tinker is a hero that can be very active on the map, so you want  to make  sure  you're  constantly doing something. This could be split pushing, ganking, or farming jungle camps.  The key is to always be doing something productive. 

Thirdly, you  should consider adjusting your skill build. Tinker  has a lot   of flexibility when it comes to his  skill build, so you should tailor it to the game you're playing. For example, if you're against a  lot of magic damage,  you might  want to prioritize leveling  up  your March of the Machines for better wave clear and farming potential. 

Lastly, communication with your team is key. Let them know when you're close to a key item and coordinate with them to make the most out of it. Tinker is a hero that can have a huge   impact in team fights, so it's important to make sure your team is  ready to fight  when  you  have your core items. 

Overall, achieving better item  timing with Tinker requires a combination of efficient farming, constant activity,   adjusting your  skill build, and  good  communication with your team. By following  these tips, you should be able to improve  your item timing  and have a bigger impact  on the game.

I've been experimenting with different laning combos  lately and I've found one that has been working really well for me.  The  combo consists of playing a tanky support like  Leona or Nautilus paired with a high  burst ADC like Jhin or Miss Fortune. 

The idea behind this combo is  to  have the tanky  support engage  on the enemy  ADC  or support, while the  burst  ADC follows  up with their high damage abilities. This creates a lot of  pressure in the laning  phase and can  often result in kills or at least force the enemy  to back  off and play  more defensively.

The  tanky support provides a lot of crowd control  and durability,  allowing the ADC to freely  deal damage without worrying too much about getting caught out. Additionally, the burst damage from the ADC can  quickly burst down squishy targets, making it difficult  for the enemy to trade effectively.

I've found that this combo works particularly well against squishy supports like Janna  or Soraka, as they are more vulnerable to the engage  and burst damage. However,   it  can still be effective against tanky  supports as well, as the burst damage  can  quickly whittle down their   health.

Overall, I've been having a lot  of success with  this laning combo and I would highly  recommend giving it  a try if  you're looking for  a strong and aggressive laning phase. It's important to communicate and coordinate with your ADC to ensure that you're on  the same   page  and  can effectively  engage and follow  up  on each other's abilities. Give it a shot and let  me know how it  works  for you!

I mean seriously, why do we have a  whole category for mil-sim? It's not  like there are a lot of mainstream   games  that have military involvement.  Shouldn't it be a subset of the action genre? RPG? Strategy? Something? It's always one   of the first categories I  eliminate when  searching for a game, because 99% of  it is just mediocre. With the tiny minority of  excellent games that deserve to be playing, it feels like a  clutter category that does more harm than good.

I guess what I'm asking is, should I be eliminating the "mil-sim" category  games  altogether, or  is that genre simply not for me? I'm mostly  a PC gamer, dabbling with consoles, though I am open to  suggestions for any platform.

I've  tried ARMA and a few other  similar games,  and they seem cool, but hard to get into after  spending most of my time in more traditional  gaming genres. Any recommendations would be welcome.

I did try searching, but most threads on the  topic seem to be complaints about lack  of mil-sim  AAWWWWWWHHHYYYYYY!!!!11 and  Sturgeon's law concerning the   low quality meme games  cluttering the category, with few actual useful opinions.

Edit: Thanks for the  suggestions guys. Apparently the  genre   has enough good  games  to warrant its  own category, who'd have thought. I'll definitely    look into these  further, and I think   I'll remove the "shooter" category from my search criteria as well  (though arena shooters are  still okay, since I do   like the occasional rocket  jumping session)

Edit 2: I should probably clarify that by "military  sim" I mean games that  strive for realism, whether  in  terms of gameplay, physics, or whatever makes the game fall into that   category. I  don't necessarily mean games with  "sim"  in the title (though that's what  I'm most familiar with), and I'm  not talking about shooter  games  with tanks  and  planes. War Thunder would probably fall under that category, but  since my aversion is mostly  due to personal taste and not the quality of the games  in  said category, I didn't really think it would be fair to  use that example.  Apologies for any confusion.

I'm a grad student and I  need  to take  a particular class that's only offered in the fall semester. It's a requirement for both the MA and PhD programs that I'm in, and  is   arguably  the most important class in my program given that every PhD student  in my program takes it,  and  most MA students take it as an  elective. 

The problem is  that I cannot  take it in the fall due to  a number of factors outside my control - travel for  work  and an intense semester for another class that I'm taking - and registering for it in  the  fall  would mean that   I  would not be  able to finish my degree within the standard timeframe for my program. 

Registration  for  the fall semester opens up tomorrow, and  I saw that there was one  section  of the class offered  in the spring. I emailed the professor who teaches the class asking if there was a possibility of another section being added in the spring, and while they very kindly forwarded my email to the  department chair, they said there were no plans for another section.  

I emailed the department chair  directly,  and apparently they are "happy to forward [my email] to the dean"   but are "not  optimistic" about the chances of another section being added.  I feel like  the dean is the next person to  go to in this chain,   but  I'm  not sure  who to email  - the  graduate admissions  dean, the  undergraduate admissions dean, the school dean? If anyone has any advice on   who to email and how  to phrase the email  so that I might actually get a response, I would  really appreciate it!

Sorry  for  the  rambling, I'd  just be  grateful  for some  advice/similar experiences! Thanks  :)

Some thoughts  which pop up in my mind are distinctly under my control. I could just let them be,  or I could think more   about them, or pursue theme.g. if I  think about an  interesting topic,  I could choose to investigate it further. Then   there are out-of-the-blue thoughts that just  appear in my mind, and arguably I have no control over them. It would be absurd to try to will myself to stop thinking about them. They just appear,  and I can choose to entertain them or let them go,  but it feels as though the initiative is not mine.

Which category   do volitional  thoughts  belong to? It seems like  they should belong to the first category, but maybe not? What determines whether a thought  is under my control? Surely  it's  not  sufficient to just feel as though I had control, because it seems some involuntary thoughts feel involuntary, even though I could make myself think about  them if I so chose. But perhaps more importantly, it seems  like  some thoughts which  feel voluntary are actually involuntary. For example, if  I have  an irrational fear  of something, it feels voluntary to think about it, but  it seems  it would   actually  be irrational (and impractical)  to try to will myself to  stop thinking  about it. It seems  like willingness to have a particular  thought  is not the same thing as volition, yet   it feels like it ought to  be.

Maybe a more charitable way of putting it is that it seems like   willingness to have a particular conscious  experience  is not the same thing as voluntariness. Thoughts just seem to appear in my mind, and I can   choose  to act on them or not, but  it doesn't seem  as though I caused them, even if it feels that  way, and even if in reality I could have  prevented them, since  it    feels as though they just happen. Conversely, other thoughts feel as though  I caused them, but it seems  as though  what matters is  not whether the thought  appeared because I willed it,  but rather whether I  could   have prevented   it. Perhaps it doesn't matter  whether a  thought is caused  by my   will, but rather whether I could have  prevented the thought, in which case all thoughts are involuntary.

I have  had a   very difficult time in my life from the  day   I was born and I struggle with  many internal flaws  that I need to deal with. I was abused as a child into my  teenage years by an outsider  to my family  dynamic (a man my mom met when  I was 3), which caused a lot of  issues in my  brain  as it formed, and I am autistic which makes  me extremely sensitive to everything,  especially conflict, whether it be external or internal.  As a  result of  that, I suffer from terrible anxiety and  depression, and I am constantly second-guessing everything I do or say, predicting the future outcomes  of all possible interactions I  could have with others  because   I can't read tones well and I  misread facial expressions  a  lot,  and I am always left feeling like I've disappointed someone, even when that's not the  case. 

I am  in  my 30s and I still live with my mom because I have never been able  to hold a job for more  than  a few  months because  of  my   anxiety and depression, which causes me to either quit or be fired.  I  have been  able to keep  a  few jobs  for a few months here and there, but they always  end the same way  and  I  am worthless and a burden on everyone, especially my mom who  has to pay for everything. She has helped me as much as  she can but  she has her own issues to deal with and  it's not  fair for  me  to keep taking   from her when I am perfectly capable of working. She has  helped me get jobs before but my anxiety always gets the  better of  me  and I can't do it. 

I am constantly fighting with  myself to try and be better but  I always end up in the same place: worthless, pathetic, and a burden on everyone around me. I am a  failure as  a person and I deserve to suffer for what I've done. I am  a terrible person and I deserve to be punished for the things  I have done.  I am  not worth  the  air I breathe and  I am a danger to society. My brain is poison and getting rid of me  would  serve  everyone, especially the universe, because the last thing it needs is another abomination like me lurking around, pretending  that I deserve to be here  when I so clearly do not. The world would be  a  better  place without me in it.

I   never really appreciated the way music can change the lives   of many, like my grandmother. My  grandmother  is a hard working woman, and she has always been a musician, my mother being a former  band member of one of her country singers.  She has also been a huge advocate  for helping people with   disabilities. And she had a  real problem in her early  life, since  she  was very bright, her legs would always ache,   her body would shake, and  even when she was on the best of  days,  things  would  hurt. At  the same  time she never really  questioned,  as she always looked at  everyone else with an air of  knowing  what was right and what was  wrong. Then, she  would have  music to help the day  go by. At her height of being, before she  was married I don't know how old  I was, my grandparents could have told she was a star. She  did go to many concerts, but most of the time she would sit in her backyard singing with her husband. Most of them didn't  really seem at   a big deal, but she took my grandma to  a concert one time and after the show, she sat on a bench  with her,  she kept looking at her  with her huge eyes,  "Are you ok  grandma?" She never looked at my grandmother the  same ever since  she  had that episode.

On the last day  before she  died, she told  my grandma that the first day on the road  with this band it was rough. She said she never  really knew  how to handle the loudness, the attention, etc.  When they  first starting playing, she said that it felt like they made her realize she was different than everyone else. She  said "it  is your destiny" and they were all a part of it. She  told my grandma, "they are not strangers, your family knows who you are and  you can talk  to them about it on the way  home."  I think my grandmother just heard that in her heart, it wasn't in her  words. She was a  big believer  in   that they were part of her family, she never let them  let her   down. After  the show she finally admitted, that  she wasn't  OK with the   way  they were looking at her. It felt like as  soon as people  got really  close to her, she would just  start shaking, her body would shake, she would start screaming  and  not know why. There was

I am not sure if  this has been mentioned before, but I have noticed that WMR is  always in  sleep  mode and never wakes up. It's like  it's asleep  all the time. I've tried  to turn on  the   radio or TV, but  nothing  happens.  I can't  get it to wake up.  I'm pretty sure it's because it's using its own power  source (probably battery) to keep itself awake. I don't know how long it will stay in sleep mode, but  I hope it doesn't go off for good.

This  is   an interesting  question. The  answer  is  yes, it does use  its own  power supply. But  it also uses some external power sources as  well. In fact, it uses two different types of  power supplies. One is a standard  AC adapter  that you might find at your local electronics store. This is what powers the computer. The other  type of power supply is a solar panel.  This is what powers the camera.

Solar  panels  are  great for powering laptops, tablets, phones, etc., but  they're  not so great for powering cameras. They require a  lot more energy than  normal batteries do.  So,  while the laptop may be powered by a solar panel,  the camera is still going to need  a regular battery.

So, why would   WMR use a solar  panel?  Well, there are several reasons. First, it's  cheap. A solar panel costs about $1 per watt. That means that a  solar  panel could provide enough juice to run the camera for  about 10  hours. Second, it's easy to install. You just plug it into the wall and  connect it  to the  USB port on  your computer. Third, it's portable. If  you want to  take the camera  with you, you can simply leave it plugged in.  Fourth, it's  very efficient.  Solar  panels convert sunlight directly into electricity. When you put a solar panel on top  of a house, it converts  the  heat from  the sun into electricity. And since the sun shines most of the day, it's perfect  for powering a camera.

But, there's  one problem  with solar panels. They only work during the  daytime. During the night, the sun stops shining. So, if you  want to charge  your camera during the day,  you'll need to either buy a backup battery  or make sure that your camera is set to automatically switch  off after sunset.

Understanding   and optimizing item timings with Tinker  can  dramatically improve  your  gameplay.  Here are some  tips you  can utilize:

1. **Prioritize  Boots of Travel (BoT):** Your first priority should always be saving for Boots of Travel. This item  is crucial  to Tinker's playstyle as it allows you  to travel around  the map, pushing lanes, and teleporting back to your base when needed.

2.  **Farming Patterns:**  Tinker is all about  farming efficiently. Using March of the Machines, you can continually clear out waves of creeps. When  farming the jungle,  move strategically  between  camps  to use March  of the Machines  to best effect.

3. **Stacking Neutral Creeps:** While farming  waves with March, try to stack  neutral  camps whenever possible, this will allow for maximizing your gold and experience gain.

4. **Bottle and Soul Ring:** These two items should be your next  priority after  BoTs.  They  give   you  the ability to  stay on the map longer due to sustainability  in health  and mana.

5. **Blink Dagger Timing:** Blink Dagger is another high priority item. Try to get it before the 20-minute mark. It offers a great deal of  mobility and  can save you from many sticky situations.

6. **Scythe  of Vyse and Dagon:** These are  your luxury items.  The former is great for control and adding an extra layer of disable in team fights, whereas  the latter  will   let you  burst down enemies quickly. Their timings   largely depend on how well you have farmed.

Remember that both  your individual skill  level  and the state of your specific game can affect this schedule. Being adaptable is crucial in Dota 2, so be prepared to adjust  your playstyle and item  build based on  the  needs of your team and the nature of the enemy team.  In general, ensure you maximize   farming, manage your mana well  and aim for minimum deaths. Good luck!

I've  been playing a  lot of duo queue  recently and stumbled  upon a laning combo that has  been surprisingly effective.  I've been playing as Thresh and my duo partner has been playing as Lucian. 

Thresh's crowd   control abilities combined with  Lucian's high burst damage has  been a deadly  combination. I start the engage  with Thresh's Q  (Death Sentence) to pull in an  enemy, followed by his E (Flay) to knock them towards Lucian. Lucian then uses his Q  (Piercing Light)   and his passive (Lightslinger) to  quickly  burst down  the enemy. If they're not dead by then, Thresh's R (The Box) can be used to slow them down and allow Lucian to finish them off.

This  combo has been working really well for  us in  the  bot lane. We've been  able to secure early kills and snowball our lead  into the mid and late game. It's also  a lot of fun  to play!

I'd love to hear about any other laning combos that you guys   have found to  be effective.  Let's share  and learn from each other!

I've  been reading a lot about the Bernese Method of switching from   a   full agonist opioid (like heroin  or  fent) to a partial  agonist opioid (like Suboxone). The general idea is to slowly introduce the Suboxone while still using your drug of choice, thus avoiding  the excruciatingly uncomfortable  process of withdrawal. This differs greatly from the  traditional  method of waiting until you are in withdrawal before beginning  to use Suboxone.

However, my primary concern  with this method is  the  prolonged exposure to the full agonist opioid  which  maintains  the addictive   behavior and potentially  damaging lifestyle. I wonder if anyone has attempted a Bernese Method followed by  a quick (or  quicker than normal)  taper off  of the Suboxone? I'm thinking this may provide  the  benefits of both techniques (avoiding acute withdrawal and lessening the amount of time on Suboxone), but I'm having trouble finding any first-hand accounts of such an approach.  I'm particularly interested in hearing about  the experience, difficulty, and effectiveness of this method,  so if you have any insight or  personal stories, your contribution would be  highly appreciated. 

Also,  I would like to note that it's incredibly important to consult with a healthcare  professional  before attempting something like this,  for anyone reading this post who might be considering it, please ensure you're receiving monitoring   and support from professionals. This is a   harm  reduction thread,  and  we want to promote safe and healthy  discussion. Thanks in advance for any responses!

I've been thinking about this for a while now  and  I believe that wearing  a full set of leather armor should improve your  sneakiness in the game. 

Leather  armor is often associated with thieves, rogues, and assassins in fantasy settings  due to its lightweight and  quiet nature. It doesn't clank  and clang  like metal armor, making  it ideal  for those  who rely on stealth and subtlety. 

In the game, this could translate to  a slight boost in sneakiness or stealth when wearing a full set of leather  armor. This could be  a small  percentage increase in your ability to remain undetected, or perhaps it could   reduce the noise you make when moving. 

This would not   only  add a layer of realism  to the game, but it would also    give players more strategic options   when planning their  character's build and playstyle.  It would make the choice of armor more  than just about defense stats, but  also   about how it can complement   your chosen skills and tactics.

What do you  guys think? Would this be a good addition to the game?  Or do you think it would  unbalance things? I'd love to hear your thoughts.

I'm frustrated with my HR  department. I recently applied for  a promotion within my company, and after going through  the interview process, I was told that I would  be receiving a job offer soon. However, when   I followed up  with HR  to ask about the status of my application, they informed  me that they couldn't provide me with  a salary range for  the position.

I found  this strange, as it's common  practice in our  industry to share salary ranges during the  hiring process  so that candidates have an idea of what  to expect. When  I  pressed them further,  they claimed that they couldn't give me a range because  "it varies based on experience" - which is a pretty  vague reason if you   ask me.

What's even  more annoying  is that they seemed to take offense to my questioning. They   started getting defensive  and dismissive, telling me that  they were "doing their best" and that I should just  wait  patiently for the offer  letter. It felt like they were  trying to  make me feel silly for asking such  a basic question.

Has anyone else  had similar experiences with their HR department? Am I overreacting  here?  I understand that delays  can happen, but the lack of transparency and condescending attitude  from HR  has left a bad taste in  my mouth.

Hey fellow Redditors,

I know a  lot of people think the Batman prep time argument is silly or  overdone, but I'm here to argue that it's actually a good thing.

First of all, let's acknowledge that Batman is a highly skilled and experienced crimefighter.  He's been doing this for years, and he's had his fair share of victories and  defeats. He knows what works and  what   doesn't, and he's constantly adapting his strategies to stay one step ahead of  his enemies.

Now, when it comes   to prep time, Batman is meticulous. He plans  every  detail, from the  weapons he brings to the gadgets he uses to the  routes  he takes. He's not just winging it,  hoping for the best.  He's a  tactician, and he knows that every second  counts.

But here's the thing: Batman's prep time isn't just about him. It's  about his allies, too. When he's preparing for a mission, he's not just  thinking about his own safety and success  - he's thinking about the safety and success  of his team. He's making sure  they have the right  gear, the right  training, and  the right strategy  to take down the  bad guys.

And  let's   not forget, Batman's not just fighting crime for the sake   of it. He's  fighting  for justice, for   what's right.  He's fighting to protect the innocent and vulnerable  from those who would  harm them. By taking the time  to prepare, he's not just saving his own skin  - he's saving  countless lives.

So  the  next time someone  says the Batman prep time argument is silly, just remember: it's not just about Batman.   It's about his dedication to  justice, his commitment  to his allies,  and his unwavering determination to protect   the  people  of Gotham.

Thanks for  reading, fellow Redditors. Let me know what you  think!

So yeah,  any advice or insights you can  offer  will be  greatly appreciated as I navigate  through this  awkward situation.

Becoming an auntie means taking  on a  new role in the lives of your siblings' children. It can be challenging, but  it  is also incredibly rewarding. There  are so many  amazing moments that come with being an auntie:

1. Watching them grow and  learn  new things
2. Sharing your wisdom and experiences  with them
3. Teaching them valuable life lessons
4. Having fun  and spending quality time together
5. Seeing their facial expressions when you give them something they love, whether it be candy or a toy
6. Hearing   about all their  milestones, from first  steps to  graduation
7. Helping out whenever they  need someone  to watch over them or  talk to them
8. Shaping them  into   better  adults by providing guidance and discipline
9. Becoming like a second parent for some (which can  help relieve  the workload from the primary   caregivers)

Overall, becoming an  auntie comes  with its own unique set of challenges and  responsibilities, but it  is also one of the most fulfilling  roles  to have. It gives me great joy to see my family thrive, and I  enjoy doing  everything  in  my power to make sure they do!

I want you  to feel sick, disgusted,  and depressed. I  want you to take pills and be an addict. I want  you to feel like crap and blame the government for your problems (sorry, you created  it). I  want you to feel  like shit  but keep  quiet. I want you to go into depression and  self-destructive  habits  instead of taking responsibility  for being unfulfilled.

I  don't  want you to know that you  are the reason you are unhappy, and that you could change the way you  view and interact with the world in  order to make it an  enjoyable place  for you. I actually want you to stay  unfulfilled, miserable,  and unhappy. I want you to go  to hell but  not know you are  going.

Why? Because a miserable world  with people who  don't want to help them means that for  every million people there are a million problems to be solved. So if you  want to feel like shit and be miserable but not  do  anything to help yourself  or others, that's what it  means for me. You're helping  me make money.

But that might be an unintended  effect of  my actions, and not my real motiveso I have another reason to be here.  I'm really here to be  a martyr.  A loudmouth, self-righteous, in your  face  martyr  who  refuses to do anything  about the world being unfair,  because it    sucks. I'm  just going to sit  here  in my chair, write these pointless blog posts, and  complain.

I'll never be   able  to get back in shape because I don't want to, and  any exercise plan you give  me or any  health tips on  eating I'll  argue to the death. People need  to keep fat because it keeps you warm  on  cold winter days, or  any day, or any time, and any other excuse you can think of, I can dispute.
